column8: Amazing experience volunteering with elephants at Pinnawala
column11: We volunteered here for 4 days and had the best time. We spend a couple of hours in the morning cleaning the stalls and refreshing the elephants food supplies (50kg per elephant), then helped out with the public elephant feeding. A couple of hours off over the middle of the day and then spent time bathing the elephants at the river from 2-4pm before following them back up the street and settling them for the night. We saw some reviews complaining that the elephants were chained- yes some are - the males particularly when they are in musk - wanting to mate and overnight. We understood the rationale for this - to protect themselves and each other at night - they all had their own stalls with plenty of food, but we did see neighbours trying to steal food from each other. Also when they are in musk they are more unpredictable. These are huge animals and so on occasions the public do need to be protected from potential risks. We only saw amazing care and attention given to the elephants from the staff, yes there is some shouting ‚Ä¶.. think trying to get a load of teenagers off the playing field. The mahouts do carry long sticks with a hook - an ankush, again this is to guide the elephants - they hook the hook over the elephants ears to direct them. We never saw them being ill treated with the ankush. The public can pay to bath the elephants and we did this as part of our volunteering - the elephants did seem to enjoy this and were so relaxed during the experience. Most of these elephants are working elephants who have been rescued and are used to direction and work. We never saw any riding of the elephants by the public at all. We were very impressed with how clean everything was behind the scenes and how the staff really cared for the elephants. We saw the vets in action as well as the mahouts caring for their particular elephants. Everyone does need to remember that these are enormous animals and it is a privilege to see them close up, but it isn‚Äôt in the wild and it isn‚Äôt a zoo. The animals here are well cared for, have spaces to roam around and head down to the river each day where they freely wander and play in the water. We also saw some complaints about the cost of visiting, especially as a foreigner.  When we were there there were 65 elephants, needing circa 50kg of food each day and with over 200 staff working there. All these costs occur 255 days a year irrespective of the visitor numbers. Consider how much you would have to pay for such an amazing experience in your home countries. We felt the price was very fair.

column8: Not the Pinnewala that we remember
column11: We are a family of four: two adults and two teens. My husband and I had visited Pinnewala about 16years ago. We had very fond memories of the place and were keen to return. I wish we hadn't. We visited after having experienced a safari drive at Minneriya National Park. Pinnewala has changed significantly.  We arrived late afternoon and headed straight to the river to see the elephants bathe. There must have been about 20 elephants in the river. The staff in green t-shirts advised you to stand in specific spots to pose with the elephants. They are clearly trained to command: lots of trunks came up and we were encouraged to buy small bags of guavas to feed them. The staff took my phone and snapped LOTS of photos of us, as well as another person's child. The elephants were restrained back by the river by a male with a long stick and a metal prod at the top. They were pushed back about 2-3times in the 20mins we were there. There was also a staff member directing a huge hose of cooling river water across the elephants backs. As soon as the staff gave my phone back, he demanded a tip. Then he kept asking for tips for his colleagues, before telling me that I should tip more. We took our time to head back to the park. The entire area becomes like a ghost town as soon as the elephants have walked through. We entered the park, which had jurassic park/ empty zoo vibes. Lots of lovely green fields and trees....... .....And all of the elephants that we saw were all chained. About 20 of them. Most kept in individual pens-styled areas. They had grass in front of them to eat. But we saw a young elephant who just wouldn't eat, and instead kept shaking its head, rocking on its legs. Another female looked as though she was straining forwards against the chain on her back foot.  A (chained) bull was also shaking his head. We don't know what happened to the elephants who came to the river to bathe (as we didn't follow them back). Instead, we just saw lots who are chained up. Im not sure if any of them have the opportunity to roam around the gorgeous, lush fields that we saw. We noted that the Orphanage has a breeding programme. As my husband wryly pointed out, this helps ensure a positive amount of 'stock' to keep the venue going. Signposts proudly state that there are about 40females and just under 30 male elephants. We probably stayed less than an hour in the park. After all, how long can you just look at chained elephants who are quietly eating long grass that's put in front of them. All in all, not what we remember from Pinnewala all those years ago. If you want an ethical experience, seeing elephants roaming freely, then do your research. Sri Lanka has a lot of parks that will offer you a wonderful glimpse into their natural habitat and lives.

Pinnawala is a village in Sri Lanka, renowned for its Elephant Orphanage. Established in 1975, this unique institution serves as a sanctuary for orphaned, injured, and abandoned elephants, offering them care and protection. Situated on a former coconut plantation along the Maha Oya River, Pinnawala provides a spacious environment for these majestic creatures. What began with just a handful of elephants has grown into the largest herd in captivity in the world. Visitors have the opportunity to witness the daily lives of these gentle giants, including their feeding times, where baby elephants are bottle-fed, and their refreshing baths in the river, a spectacle of playful interaction. While primarily a conservation center, Pinnawala has also become a significant tourist attraction, drawing both locals and international visitors eager to get up close with elephants. The income generated from tourism helps sustain the orphanage's operations and the well-being of its residents. The success of Pinnawala's captive breeding program has also contributed to its growth, with numerous births occurring within the sanctuary. These elephants, often orphaned due to human-wildlife conflict or natural incidents, find a safe haven here. Although not a completely natural habitat, Pinnawala strives to offer a life of care and security for these rescued animals, many of whom would not survive in the wild on their own.

Reading reviews of Pinnawala Elephant Orphanage, it is clear that opinions are deeply divided. Many visitors express concerns about elephants being chained or guided forcefully, while others criticize the very existence of an institution where elephants interact with humans. However, these critiques often lack an understanding of the difficult realities faced in Sri Lanka‚Äôs human-elephant coexistence. Yes, some elephants are sometimes chained‚Äîbut is the alternative better? Some of these elephants are aggressive due to past trauma, and without restraints, they could pose serious danger to both humans and other elephants. Is the alternative to euthanize every elephant that becomes difficult to manage? When we visited Pinnawala, we made a conscious effort to see beyond the surface. We witnessed elephants bathing in the river, enjoying their meals, and interacting with caretakers who, for the most part, demonstrated genuine care and expertise. The orphanage is home to elephants that have been orphaned, injured in train accidents, or displaced due to conflicts with farmers. Without a facility like this, many of these elephants would not survive. Sri Lanka‚Äôs Buddhist culture places a strong emphasis on protecting life, which is why injured and disabled elephants are not euthanized as would have been in Europe. Instead, they are given a chance at life‚Äîsometimes with visible scars or disabilities that might make visitors uncomfortable, but which are a testament to the efforts made to save them. Pinnawala is government-run, and its existence plays a vital role in Sri Lanka‚Äôs broader conservation challenges. Hundreds of elephants die every year due to human-wildlife conflict, particularly through train accidents and electric fences near farmlands. Investing in facilities like Pinnawala helps not only the elephants but also the people who live alongside them by promoting education and sustainable solutions. Pinnawala has veterinarians that travel the country and help elephants in, an outside the orphanage. This can be assistance with landmine or train accidents in the country side of Sri Lanka. Without visitors there is no economy for this. Is Pinnawala perfect? No. Ethical concerns surrounding elephant tourism should always be addressed, and improvements should be encouraged where needed. But dismissing a place like this entirely ignores the complex reality of conservation in a developing country. The truth is, without tourism, there would be little economic incentive for local communities to protect elephants, and their habitats would suffer as a result. Our visit left us with a greater appreciation for the delicate balance between conservation, cultural traditions, and economic survival. Pinnawala is not a flawless sanctuary, but it is an important part of Sri Lanka‚Äôs elephant conservation efforts‚Äîone that deserves a more nuanced conversation rather than black-and-white judgment. Visit, spend some money, choose the activities that you feel are ethical and help them  become even better at helping these huge, amazing animals.

We consider elephants as auspicious and if you get the oppurtunity to feed, bathe, pet and ride an elephant well then Pinnawala elephant orphanage checks all the list. An amazing g place. Watching them walk you can sing ' tauba yeh matwaali chal. ...' feeding them was so fulfilling. And when bathing them they return the favor. A must visit to appease the animal lover and mom in you.

On the last day of our round trip we asked our driver to let us see the elephant orphanage. Online is a suggested length of stay of 3 hours. I'll get to that later. Once at the orphanage, we were amazed that the prices were so high. 15 euros admission per capita for an orphanage? Is that a donation? Well, we could still swallow that. Less than 60 seconds in the park, we were confronted with 2 options: 1. Walking with elephants for another massive fee. 2. Elephants feed for an extra charge. A single elephant was brought in and stuffed with bananas by a horde of tourists. Some would say ‚Äúhey, they‚Äôre being fed what are you complaining about‚Äù. The elephants were forcibly held, beaten against the lower part of the trunk with horse mackerel, or pulled hard by the ear, while a horde of tourists took pleasure in watching a trained, fearful elephant and taking great photos. This so-called orphanage is an absolute nightmare for every animal lover and creature lover. Here money is made at the expense of the animals. This has nothing to do with animal love. Much worse, the animals are held here with chains under the guise of safety. A really disgusting place, I wouldn't recommend anyone in this world to go there. At the end of our 15 minutes we spent there and then disgustingly stopped, we were asked by a guide to a gift shop.

We stayed in a hotel in Pinnawala for 3 days. This allowed us to see more than the people who come there as tourists for an afternoon. we also asked a lot of questions to the people; like why some elephants are chained and some are not. Answer was for the safety of animals and humans. Some elephants grow up in the area with the caretakers/have lived there for a long time, they are used to interaction with people (no different). However, animals that have been rescued from dire situations/found as orphans in nature still have to get used to the situation with people around them. this is understandable so far. but if you pay close attention you will see that some keepers are working underwater to poke the animal with their stick, to force them to lie down in the river for a bath. so this is not a voluntary choice of the elephant at that moment. it has to be for the photo that the tourists want to take while cuddling/washing the elephant. we saw elephants struggling and trumpeting in pain/anger. heartbreaking. The pricking is probably used to create respect/fear for the caregiver. Once abused enough, the elephant will listen without prodding, making it appear as if the animal is listening 'voluntarily'. in short the initiative of this project will be really good otherwise the animals might be orphaned/exploited for hard work. but the fact remains that where money can be made, people use power to get this money, including the government...

DREADFUL PLACE....I feel so guilty that I visited there. A pure scam!! Elephants used to make easy money for a few ruthless people. Also, I was robbed out of a lot of money there...I paid by Visa Debit and didnt notice that extra zeros were added and I was charged ‚Ç¨132 instead of ‚Ç¨13 (they charged for my driver also)...my own fault. I didnt check before I put in my pin number and didnt see what was taken from my account until a week later. I was south in Galle by then. Losing so much money was one thing, but the pathetic effort at trying to convince us that this was a caring "sanctuary" was another!

Avoid this place if you are traveller from any South Asian Country as you would have seen better facility at reasonable cost. The place is just an orphanage to take care of sick/abandoned/old elephants and the ticket pricing is very high for what it offers! Mostly you will see elephants chained and standing for long time and is painful. There is a discount for SAARC country passport holders but avoidable. Instead buy a separate ticket for elephant bathing as that is something you will enjoy.

The reviews are mixed, I found the experience exceptional you can see their breakfast at 9am and follow up with their bath, remember to take an extra ticket to bathe with the elephant. Elephants are taken below directly into the river only a few left to take a bath with you surrounded by the right team who take your videos and photo souvenirs (against tip at the end) for us it was clearly worth it

If you go here and pay to ‚Äúbathe or ride‚Äù or even watch these elephants, you are part of the problem. These elephants are being paraded daily for tourist and people are being told ‚Äúthis is the elephant‚Äôs only option for a life in Sri Lanka‚Äù This needs to stop!
Do not go here!! You all are contributing to this abuse if you do. Stop harming animals. Shame on everyone who is actively supporting this group or any who harm the animals.
Marvelous, best place to feed and wash elephants. Orphanage is for  elephants that need care and so they won‚Äôt go back to jungle, people can touch them.

Frankly, we expected more. In the territory of elephants you can feed fruit, which is sold in a separate plate, they take bananas and pineapples from their hands, it is very funny. Then the elephants at a certain time are led in formation across the road to the river to swim, all traffic stops. Lots of tourists and specialty shops.

Good location and nice views. But very poor management and service.. We went there today, purchased tickets and waited over 40 minutes for the short elephant ride ( of less than 10 minutes). But in the chaotic situation everybody else went in front ( possibly they had greased the palms of the guides). And the staff also were very rude So I was disgusted enough to leave it altogether I made a formal complaint and left
Please don't go there. They chain the elephants and use sticks to make them listen. Not natural or animal friendly throughout the...

This is abuse. This establishment needs to be shut down. You should not have to chain up an animal and force it into submission just so you can show it around for tourists. If you visit here you are a terrible person.

What a lovely experience.  The sanctuary is well organised.  On arrival after we purchased our tickets we were directed to the river to watch the bathing.  Here you can get a drink. The keepers let me feed the elephants. The shops on the street are only accessible if you have a ticket. There was no hassle and it was a pleasant day. Inside the sanctuary you can watch the elephants and feed them . Everything was clean and well managed.  Importantly the elephants looked content.

Elephants are beautiful animals and touching one is an exciting experience. The mission of the Orphanage is also commendable: it was founded by the Sri Lankan Wildlife Conservation Department in 1975 to "feed and provide care and shelter to orphaned baby elephants that were found in the wild". And, let's be clear, they seem to have all the best practices on animal welfare. But you should know that the Pinnawala Elephant Orphanage is a tourist attraction of great appeal for both Sinhalese and foreigners and therefore seems to be in a crowded zoo and certainly not among animals in the wild. The cost is not cheap but the ticket also includes "elephant bath".

It was an amazing experience to be able to see so many elephant and to have the opportunity to feed them. There should be given more freedom, though. The option of bathing was also nice. What was not nice was the demand of tips. Overall, a beautiful place üëçüèøü©µ

Pinnawala Elephant Orphanage is a must-visit for wildlife enthusiasts! Located in Sri Lanka, it offers a rare chance to observe elephants up close in a caring environment. Watch them bathe in the river and enjoy feeding sessions. It's a heartwarming experience blending nature, culture, and unforgettable memories.
Sadly this is not about the elephants and should be avoided . Chained bull elephants for 3 months due to elephants in season. Others in pens with no access to water and clearly distressed .

column6: Camilas Dabarera from Stevin Lanka Tours
column11: I had the pleasure of witnessing a group of elephants up close as they enjoyed munching on coconut trees, and it was truly unforgettable! Watching these gentle giants reach up to pull down branches, crack open coconuts, and skillfully strip the leaves was mesmerizing. They seemed so at ease, moving gracefully and occasionally looking over at us with curious glances. This experience offered such a raw connection to nature, and it was clear that the elephants were well-cared-for and respected in this environment. It‚Äôs rare to be able to see wildlife like this in such a natural setting, and I‚Äôd recommend it to anyone wanting to connect with these beautiful creatures. A perfect mix of excitement and serenity ‚Äì five stars all the way!

Arrived here early morning before the crowds. Purchased some fruit baskets to feed the elephants. Lovely experience, so gentle.  The elephants have a very large area to roam and are taken down to the river to spend time bathing etc. We had lunch by the river with fabulous views as the elephants had some time to bathe, dust bath, body scrub and enjoy their time. Would recommend  a visit to anyone with a love for these wonderful animals.

Such a great cause and I would recommend going as it was nice to walk around and see the elephants. However, it wasn‚Äôt as advertised they‚Äôd said there was baby elephant bottle feeding which is one thing I‚Äôd have loved to do but this wasn‚Äôt the case. The babies were very much feeding off mums rightly so, yet they advertised feeding three times per day. We were staying at one of the hotels on the river bank so we were able to see the herd each day which was a wonderful experience and we had a lovely few days. The handlers take the elephants to the river twice a day for them to bath and play it was an incredible experience I‚Äôd recommend staying in one of these hotels instead of visiting the actual orphanage if you‚Äôre wanting to see them in their natural environment. The orphanage does offer elephant fruit feeding and walking with an elephant however we didn‚Äôt want to do this it was nice to see them but I‚Äôd have liked a guide to tell us more about the elephants their names why and how they ended up there. The educational said is missing but all in all I‚Äôd recommend. On a side note, there are elephants with chains on, we were told this isn‚Äôt to keep them locked away it‚Äôs only used for male elephants to protect them and help with vet procedures and to also help when walking through the villages. Bull elephants are a known to be more boisterous which you see when they‚Äôre playing in the water, they do not seem distressed or harmed.

I was heartbroken to see how much the elephant carers were abusing the elephants so that tourists could take pictures with the elephants. After the picture they were asking for money from the tourists. They kept two elephants separate from the herd and these two elephants weren‚Äôt allowed in the water. They were standing on a narrow path from two hours while other elephants went to the water. The elephants were clearly distressed, shackled and were suffering abuse from the elephant carers. It was a very sad situation to see.

I thought it was terrible. I don't recommend it at all. We went as an activity organized by the agency... and it was sold as an orphanage. As soon as you enter you see on the workers' T-shirts the word zoo. And inside you see elephants... instigated by keepers who act as shepherds. These have like a spear and at the tip like two blades. Elephants just after seeing them take their cues...more out of fear than anything else. And the worst thing was seeing two elephants chained together. Terrible looks from them... desperate for the situation. They have a sign explaining it's out of necessity. It doesn't hurt. We left right away. They sell it as an orphanage but it is not...they are elegant...mostly adults...in captivity...and ill cared for. Terrible to see them afterwards with chains that plow their legs and neck. I never thought I'd do this with them. There are national parks where you can see them in total freedom... in their natural state. These poor people are in captivity and living a bad life. It is a pity that the government of this country exploits them for pure economic interest. Terrible!!
You will be in the area to do the Safari so the visit to this elephant orphanage fits quietly. Very interesting visit in the morning when they give milk and food to the elephants.

We loved seeing the elements bathe. Being able to feed them, touching their tube is fantastic. They seem very happy. Lots of little elephants dabbling and having fun. One of our best memories of Sri Lanka. Then we saw them coming up the street: very impressive! And visited the recycled poop paper factory üí© of Elephant: huge!!!!

column6: kandy tuk tuk tours by munasingha
column11: the orphanage provides a sanctuary for orphaned, injured, and abandoned elephants. It is renowned for its efforts in conservation, education, and rehabilitation of these majestic animals.

In front of the park (near the entrance) we were approached by a man. It indicated that the elephants had just done everything and if we wanted to see them it was a bit further away. A little stunned, we walked along and had to go into a tuktuk. After 5 min drive we came to another place with indeed elephants. Entrance fee tried to set the best man 3x as high as 5 minutes before agreed, of course did not fall for that. Park apparently does nothing to prevent other companies from taking visitors to another park.

We doubt whether to visit the orphanage because of the reviews read in the forum, but we are one of those who like to live it to say, and it was certainly a total success, rarely you have the opportunity to bathe with an elephant and see them pass by in a pack in a street full of shops is impressive that scene. At no time did we see that the animals were badly treated, the chains in cases is logical they are wild animals and depends how the elephant need to have them controlled there are people very close to them, the spikes I did not see them used with the stick guide them. For me the best thing was the exit of the orphanage to the river and the river while they are bathing. They are careful and it is logical that they take advantage of tourists while doing their routine. I would certainly do it again

I went here as a university student from the UK (I was appalled that my university would even take us here). When you look on trip advisor you will see that this orphanage is listed as ‚Äúnot meeting animal welfare guidelines‚Äù do not ignore this. When I went there were elephants being made to pose for photos and be stroked in an attempt to make more money, despite the irony that most people would pay far more to see these animals in their natural habitat. Further to this, elephants were chained and would rock from side to side which they do when they are emotionally distressed. The elephants would be made to be bathed hundreds of times a day, far more than what they would like in the wild. Despite me raising concerns, of course my response was one of invalidation, denial, and gaslighting. You will be told things like ‚Äúoh this happens so we can educate tourists and the elephants get the best treatment, you don‚Äôt know what you‚Äôre talking about‚Äù. Of course anyone would see through this veneer of denial so I urge any tourists thinking of visiting to remain trusting in what your own eyes show you. It is time that this organisation takes the opinions of others seriously and does not instead turn to self denial, anyone would pay far more and would leave amazing reviews if you allowed the elephants to be left alone and instead observed from afar (this is surely far more sustainable for the business, and less morally taxing). I see that the organisation often also comments on reviews to argue their point which is not only unprofessional, it only furthers the original point made that without self awareness, there will not be real change.
AVOID AVOID AVOID ! Animals are chained and beaten!!!! Tourist trap at the elephants expense! Places like this should not exist and paying for a ticket only helps fund this animal cruelty.

A place of suffering !! It was an experience to forget, elephants are tied up whipped and forced to do what they don't want As soon as we entered we realized that what we expected did not correspond to reality, the sadness of the elephants could be seen from their eyes A real hell for them, it's a tourist trap that has nothing beautiful at all !!! I hope these animals are free to live their lives in serenity sooner or later
A place of exploitation, elephants are beaten and forced to be touched by humans A place of infinite sadness, we do not finance this wickedness towards animals Terrible experience!!
Happy Customers from Oman Mrs. Fariha Abbhas and family. 6 days 5 nights round tour. Thank you Mrs. Abbhas for the trust you had on Dream Holiday Sri Lanka By Golden Voyages Pvt Ltd.

TOURIST TRAP! Don't support it, don't come here. The entrance is extremely expensive by local standards (which I would bite). The problem is what you see inside and how they treat you and those elephants. Better spend that money on Safari, on national parks, you'll see and experience much more. Even with children it is more worthwhile to go on a Safari (in the ZOO itself and inside the orphanage you will see a couple of elephants and animals). It used to be really an orphanage for elephants, now it just looks like an orphanage and de facto animal cruelty is hidden behind it. And no, I'm not an animal protector, but for the first time in my life I was bothered by how they treat those elephants. They are also tied up while swimming in the river, if they don't listen and don't stab them... In addition, they buzz you when you take pictures, they want extra money (even if you paid for the entrance fee, which 80% of the local residents don't have...). I was here with a person who was here 15 years ago, he wondered how many elephants have decreased.. Elephants who live to a great age.. We would not be surprised if they were dead. These places should be avoided and not supported. The Sri Lankan authorities should ban this, as it spoils the tourists' impression of Sri Lanka, which is really beautiful in other places.

Very bad money-making with tortured animals. Many animals are also driven to the river in chains and allowed to bathe there, whether they like it or not. In some cases, they are chained to iron rings in the river and exhibit severe behavioral disorders. They're supposed to be chained up because they're aggressive. Why do you think? The baby feeding of the alleged orphans, who are stuffed with milk bottles in their mouths every 10 seconds by tourists for a fee, is particularly terrible. The animals are bred here, but not for release, but for the Touris. It is a zoo that is also very expensive and offers a lot of expensive activities .it to the elephants, also riding. Riding is quite bad for the animals' backs. The "No Ride compaign" of Thailand has not arrived in Sri Lanka.  I am ashamed to have fallen for the "positive" reviews. Don't go there! Do not support!

As a solo traveller I felt targeted the most as staff that wanted to get photos for me just wanted tips. It‚Äôs not a nice experience really ruined it for me to be honest. They took a video/photo of the elephant with horns and he was chained down and looked very distressed I don‚Äôt agree with these types of treatment even if the animal is dangerous he should be left to roam free somewhere. It was very staged not a natural experience poking baby elephants in the face with a stick to keep it away. I understand the nature of this project but like a lot of things in Sri Lanka has turned into a tourist trap and a business for making money more than anything it should be about animal welfare and providing a nice experience so tourists want to visit, it makes me question whether it is a sanctuary seeing the poor male elephant chained to the floor

Pinnawala is an elephant orphanage that houses orphaned baby elephants and injured elephants found in the wild. But unlike in Udawalawe, they are not rehabilitated and released back to the wild. Hence, while they are a couple of chained bull elephants, most are semi domesticated and roams around in relative freedom. Google directions to the orphanage is accurate. You have to buy tickets for entry, a nominal amount for locals. I've visited the orphanage many years ago when the highlight of the place was  feeding sessions for the baby elephants. But sadly that is no longer open to visitors. (I can understand the reason after visiting Ufawalawe ;) But you can feed them fruits at an additional fee. The insta famous part of the visit is to see them being bathed in the Maha Oya. For this you have to cross the road from the orphanage and go down a side lane. (But make sure to carry the entry ticket you bought from the orphanage as there is a checking counter mid way in the lane.) The lane is full of tourist shops and ends in a set of pavilions build by the adjoining hotels. (So if you are staying at one of those hotels, and don't use the lane mentioned above for entry, you may not need a ticket. But better check with the hotel.) You can stand at the pavilions or there are tables to sit. You can even order food and drinks (This is handled by the same hotels). But as far we could see there was no requirement to buy food and drinks to sit at the tables set up by the hotels. The bathing takes place from 10.30 - 11 30 am in the morning and 2.30 - 3.30 pm in the afternoon. (But times may change depending on the weather.) If you want to bath the elephants you have to buy another ticket from the orphanage and show it to the mahouts at the river. All in all we spent an enojoyable two hours there. Bathing will concide with hot and humid weather, so the fact that you could sit in a shade and enjoy the spectacle was a great plus point.... There is also an open air zoo just before you reach the orphanage. We visited the place couple of years of ago just as it was starting out.

On our way to Kandy from Colombo we had a stop at Pinnawala Elephant Orphanage, before this trip we planned this place for our kids and I must say that they had a great time, the best part was the bathing time of Elephant. We as an adult also had an amazing experience at this place.
The experience is not bad. Possibility to ride on the elephant and give it a bath. Prices start from $15 per adult depending on activities.

Pinnawala Elephant Orphanage, situated in Sri Lanka, has long been a cherished destination for both local and foreign tourists. This unique sanctuary started with the noble mission of sheltering orphaned elephants. Over the years, it has transformed into a haven where these majestic creatures have grown and thrived. **Ticket Prices:** - Local Visitors: LKR 250 + 18% VAT - Foreign Tourists: USD 15.00 + 18% VAT **A Journey Through Time:** My first visit to Pinnawala Elephant Orphanage was 20 years ago. Back then, one of the highlights was watching the adorable baby elephants being fed with huge milk bottles ‚Äì an incredibly heartwarming scene that drew many visitors. Unfortunately, on my latest visit, I discovered that this session is no longer available. The elephants have grown up, and the baby feeding sessions have been discontinued. **Current Attractions:** Despite the absence of baby feeding sessions, Pinnawala still offers a remarkable experience. Visitors can observe the elephants freely roaming within the sanctuary. Although direct contact with the elephants is not permitted, a designated hut for spectators provides a good vantage point to watch these magnificent animals up close. One of the enjoyable activities available is feeding the jumbo elephants with fruit plates, which can be purchased for a small fee. This interactive experience allows visitors to connect with the elephants in a unique and memorable way. **Elephant Bathing:** A visit to Pinnawala would be incomplete without witnessing the famous elephant bathing session. The elephants are led to a nearby river, where they indulge in a refreshing and playful bath. This activity not only offers great photo opportunities but also highlights the playful nature of these gentle giants.

Bull elephants chained in river, rest of the herd looked bored except for babies who were loving it. The babies were born there not rescued. I found it a very touristy experience, however, due to declining populations these places are needed and tourist dollars enables them to survive. Surely the national parks are enough without this!

Great experience, got to feed the elephants, walk with them, wash them and get showered by them. This place takes care of injured or orphaned elephants until they are able to return to the wild. Showers are available and there is a small gift shop. A must do if you are visiting this area of Sri Lanka.

The orphanage house a large number of elephants for viewing. not too much to do and to see.. the highlight of the experience was when we were able to see and experience the washing and bathing of the elephants. we were at one of the store the herd passed by and it felt surreal. we took a picture with the elephant and the guy wants us to sit on it but we felt really uncomfortable doing that. felt bad for it. anyway, it was a new feeling watching these big beasts there.

We saw elephants bathing and returning back to their enclosures. In the souvenir shops nearby, Elephant poo paper is available, be sure to see how it is made. You can give fruits to the elephants for some cash, which is a unique experience. It was a chance to see these majestic creatures from close by.

So the thing is.. you read and hear a lot about this place and some of the bad reviews about the bad conditions that the elephants live in almost made us change our minds about going. BUT the conditions are very nice and it was a great experience! It was great to see how the elephants was able to walk and play on their own in small and bigger heads. We bathed with them and it was an incredible experience. We are so glad that we went anyway

The visit was part of our circuit and was something I was so looking forward to. However, the reality was something else. The view from the restaurant upstairs overlooking the river where the elephants were bathing was the best part of the experience until we realised that the keepers were letting tourists (for a sum of money) climb up on the elephants which were lying in the water and taking photos for them. Scandalous. As any elephant lover knows, this is pure humiliation for these giants. People shouldn't be climbing up on them. They're  just a tourist attraction. Their keepers had their hands out wanting payment for photos.  No information on the programme, nobody to ask questions to,none of the keepers are approchable.  A very disappointing place and not in the best interest of these animals. If this is a government sponsored programme, well shame on the government for not providing for these elephants. It's a pure tourist trap.

A sanctuary for the abandoned and wounded elephants in Sri Lanka. Each and every elephant is being taken care of with the best of their ability by the keepers and management. Entrance price for the orphanage for foreigners are pretty high, compared to locals. But fortunately we were able to get a discount due to the fact we are part of the SAARC region. It was fun to play with the elephant while bathing them and it was an amazing day with the giants to start our vacation in Sri Lanka, which hyped our further endeavours. We can feed the elephant in the designated areas with additional tickets available then and there in the feeding areas. All the elephants were enjoying their activities and there were some rogue elephants that were kept deep inside the orphanage to calm them down to adapt to the new environment and atmosphere. To buy souvenirs, do buy it from the State owned Lakshala Shop located within the Orphanage campus and the orphanage specific souvenirs are located here alone. Some guides might advise you to buy it from Colombo but place specific souvenirs shall be bought here itself. There are hotels and privately owned souvenirs and clothing shops outside the orphanage, where we can try our bargaining ability to bring the bang for buck...

Entrance 2 thousand rupees ($15 plus 18%). I got there from the railway station by tuk-tuk for 500 rupees one way. The nursery worker took my phone from my hand and ran off to take a photo of the elephant with its tusks. Then he came running 1-2 minutes later, demanding money for a photo of an elephant. Although I didn't need them. They sell mini fruit baskets for the elephant so you can feed it. Elephants from afar, this is a minus. I saw only 2 elephants up close - the one I fed and bathed

Extraordinary experience. The elephants seem to be genuinely happy. They go to the river morning and afternoon and are fed and graze in the mean time. Several lie in the water with the tips of their trunks breaking the surface to breathe. Visitors can feed one lucky girl for the price of a small basket of fruit! There are a couple of cranky males tethered during tourist hours which is a pity but boys will be boys. Down the road there are much more expensive private operations. Pinnawala is a Government run orphanage.
We bought the package of walking side by side with Raju as we don‚Äôt like the idea of riding them - it was an amazing experience and elephants are looking happy, very well trained

Total animal cruelty!! Simply horrible!!! The elephants are kept there under the pretense of an orphanage, but in reality they are bred there, not released back into the wild and chained up to entertain tourists and driven through the village to the river, where tourists can bathe them and the keepers sometimes ride them. The whole structure is worse than any zoo and absolute animal cruelty! In the orphanage itself they are kept in far too little space, where they also have far too little green space to gather their food.

We were expecting a rescue centre for orphaned animals. Unfortunately, we only came across a tourist hotspot where the animals are driven on chains through a shopping mall to the river several times a day. When we arrived at the park, we witnessed animals with behavioural problems. There were also too many animals in too small an area without food. In some cases, the elephants' ribs were clearly visible. A total of around 70 elephants are kept on site. According to one employee, none are released back into the wild. "They would be worse off in the wild and they wouldn't know what it's like in the wild anyway." However, when it comes to elephants that come from the wild, this is more than a lie. We were more than disappointed and sad that, despite doing our research beforehand, we supported such a company with our entrance fee.

column7: Ras Al Khaimah, United Arab Emirates
column11: I am married to a Sri Lankan, but I am often treated like a foreigner, which gets tiring. Many attractions seem to overcharge us, with only a few exceptions. Pinnawala used to be one of our favourite places to visit, but our recent trip after COVID-19 was disappointing. The prices they charged us were exorbitant compared to what we received. Sri Lanka needs to address its tourist industry's issues. We walked away without paying this time because they charged us 5200RS for foreigners, while locals paid significantly less. It was challenging to shop there too because vendors constantly tried to sell us something. We were stopped midway down the street to buy tickets to shop, making it difficult for other vendors to sell their products. During our previous visits, the streets were bustling with tourists, but now they're empty, and not in a good way. People would walk away rather than pay the inflated prices. A driver even told us that we could ride an elephant down the road for the same cost as the admission fee. It's absurd. The way foreigners are treated in Sri Lanka makes us reconsider coming back to these types of attractions. Other countries like Thailand and Taiwan treat foreigners with more respect, and their tourism industry is much better. The two-tier system currently in place in Sri Lanka is frustrating.

Went on a quick visit to the elephant orphanage. As well as paying for entry, we purchased the walking with an elephant, which we all loved, got to talk to the ranger, walk along side the elephant and touch here, with plenty of great photo ops. This was the highlight. We did feel the entry fee was way overpriced and if we did not purchase the tour it would have been disappointing  and not value for what we paid. Given 4 stars for the walk with the elephant experience.

We witnessed Elephant bathing in River ! MUST WITNESS Once in LifeTime ... well organised. It is gr8 to see so many Elephant Babies & Adults enjoying themselves and bringing so much Joy to us ! You can watch this from 8.30 to 12.30 in mornings & again after 3.30
Got to ride elephants and feed them. Also was able to have lunch by the river and watch an entire herd of elephants walk by.

A large area, there are really a lot of elephants. Both ‚Äúorganized‚Äù (under the supervision of drivers) and clearly freely walking. Elephants clearly love to bathe in the river that flows through the territory, and if you wish, you can help them with this: tourists (accompanied by attendants, of course) go down into the river, water the lying elephants, and you can rub the elephant‚Äôs back :-)

Pinnawala Elephant Orphanage in Sri Lanka is a must-visit for elephant lovers. It's home to rescued and orphaned elephants, offering a chance to observe them up close. The highlight is watching them bathe and play in the river. However, opinions on the treatment of elephants vary, with some advocating for more ethical practices. Overall, it's an experience worth considering, but with awareness of potential ethical concerns.
Such a beautiful place with lots of elephants. Feeding elephants with fruits is also an interesting part of it. Showering in the river is the most beautiful part for us. We had such a nice time.

This was my second visit. It seemed less crowded than almost a decade ago, but I can't recall if the initial trip was on a Saturday like the 2024 one. I am in two minds about this. On the positive side, one could view a small number of elephants in a reasonably sized field/paddock, and subsequently in the river.  Some were engaging in natural behaviours such as throwing mud over themselves. On the other hand, while it's understandable that what can be at times aggressive male ('bull') elephants need to be chained to walk though the street shared with souvenir shops to the river,  some maintain this is cruel. Given this is a Sri Lankan government facility, one wonders if there's mistreatment of elephants by handlers at times when the facility is closed to the public. The land area of 29 acres is probably way to small for about 70 elephants who in an open setting such as a mix of fields and forest would raam as I understand it up to 20 kilometres a day.  Notably, visitors could only see a small percentage of that number, which begs the question 'where are the rest?' Is this 'rehabilitation' or 'exploitation'? Horrific experience at Pinnawela Elephant ‚ÄúOrphanage‚Äù Me and my two friends were very excited to go to Pinnawela. Still I couldn‚Äôt bring myself to feed, bathe, let alone sit on the backs of these magestic animals, so tragically turned to a state of starvation. I could count the ribs of several of the elephants, they kept hanging their tusks and mouths over the iron gates begging for food, picking up the tiniest piece of watermelon on the ground with a lot of sand, just to have something to eat. I asked whether this doesn‚Äôt hurt the animals mentally. He said they were given medicine when they were sick and besides, in the wild, the male elephants are also separated from the group. At the end of the tour, we allowed ourselves to fully ventilate to each other about how we felt. Angry and sad, for these innocent magestic animals we had witnessed bathing and walking in a big park from the jeep, and were now reduced to bone-thin ‚Äúvehicals‚Äù (which is literally what our guide described them as) making parkinson-like shaking movements. Back and forth, back and forth some elephants wiggled their heads and body in the most unnatural-like way. When the rangers approached them with their stick (ankus or goad, proudly displayed in the orphanage), one could just see the fear in their movements, shaking and running away. I have been to many places in my life, but this was honestly the worst travel experience ever for me. Please think carefully whether you want to sponsor this kind of animal abuse.

This is not a refuge but rather a Luna park for tourists - the elephants are chained and prodded with metal sticks with spikes - a sad spectacle. Avoid avoid avoid

I have been here twice and have had the same experience everytime. this is a must see when going to Sri Lanka. Make sure you go when the elephants march to the bathing area. Check the timings in advance, and go a little early to get the tickets. you won't want to miss this.

Not worth to go. The elephant sanctuary in Sri Lanka's pinnawala town is a major sanctuary for orphaned and injured elephants. The road to the orphanage is perhaps one of the most scenic drive you may come across in Sri Lanka. The star attraction of the sanctuary was an elephant which has given birth to twins, a rarity. We were also able to see a few elephants in search of a mate. Away from the orphanage across the road the elephants were given a cool bath in the river. There are also a number of souvenir shops near the elephant bathing ghat. The parking space is spacious and the western style toilets were clean and well maintained. There is also an ATM near the entrance where the newly arrived foreign tourists can convert their home currency into Sri Lankan rupees. A fun place for kids to see elephants of all ages at close proximity. The entry fee is nominal and the place well maintained. We could not locate a restaurant in the premises. We could also see a number of birds in the surroundings. A good place to visit with the kids for a picnic. Recommended.
Our aim was to see the elephants for the children and walk close to them. It was really a good opportunity especially walking in a line to the river, a very beautiful sight.
A great place to see many elephants at one place. They look healthy and well cared for. Entry fee is higher for non-nationals as compared to nationals.

I first visited  Pinnawala 20 years ago and I was enthralled  by the way the elephants were cared for. It was joyous. I was able to spend precious time  close to the elephants that I adore.  Fast forward to 2022 when a couple of months ago we took two of our  grandchildren to relive the experience from 20 years ago. Only one word can describe it...horrendous.  Elephant welfare has been overtaken by unscrupulous keepers out to make as much money from visitors as they can. Because I was obviously carrying our money in my bag I was separated from my family by the keepers who aggressively tried to obtain R5000 from me. Every picture that you took they wanted paying for. Needless to say after a lot of shouting by me to my family and eventually joining them,  they reluctantly backed off. We then saw them hounding a young female backpacker for money. After we went to rescue her she told us she feigned not being able to understand them to thankfully not part with any money. By late afternoon the keepers went home and the orphanage was left to the mahoots to feed and care for the elephants. 3 large tuskers were chained up and exhibiting shocking distress the whole time we were there. To be fair and with just us left in the park, watching the elephants being fed was a wonderful experience. It is such a shame that the elephants, who we believe to be living in an orphanage where you expect care and kindness to be uppermost, are living in nothing more than a money making theme park. Research, and find many other orphanages in Sri Lanka, that do exactly what it says on the tin.

A tough one to review, as a brit it did seem a little odd and hard to tell what treatment the animals get, but it was an experience we wont forget - so I think you have to make your mind up based on the reviews.

This experience alone is well worth the visit, the rest of the park is average with elephants grazing in different areas.  One highlight was seeing the twin baby elephants with their mother.  There are a few informational boards scattered around the park but apart from this information was lacking.  Wear a hat and cover yourself in sunblock, take water, as there is nowhere to escape the sun. Pinnawala is a nice place where you can get close to elephants. Elephants go for a bath every day at 10.00 a.m and it is quite interesting to watch they are playing in the water.

Awful, awful and then some!  Not as expected!  Elephants chained and in distress.  The mother of twins the first born in captivity, put in an arena so small, mother showing signs of distress.  Most upsetting

Pinnawala is an area located in the town of Rambukkana in the Kegalle District of Sri Lanka.  Pinnawala is one of the major tourist destinations in Sri Lanka.  Pinnawala Elephant Orphanage is the only one in the world and the largest and only outdoor zoo in Sri Lanka.  I would love to see the amazing activities of the elephants there.

Quite a nice place to visit to see elephants free to roam around and do their thing without being chained. There are about 70 elephants here and most of them are free to roam around the property (there are tied only when under medical care or preparing to mate). Visitors have a gallery from where they can watch the elephants, and also walk around their bathing area. There is a small souvenir shop as well. They take the elephants at designated times to the river for bathing, but that was not done when we went because the river water level was very high. This can be fun for kids.

We visited this awesome place during the beginning of covid 19 pandemic situation. Place was less crowded and very quiet. We were comfortably seated and watched elephants are enjoying natural river bathing. Hope to visit again

Billed as a sanctuary for orphaned elephants, commercialism has taken over and it is no more than a glorified tourist attraction zoo. Not a pleasant site to see these majestic creatures chained up and being proded with spiked staffs.

Entry charges were LKR 800 (for SAARC adults), LKR 3500 (foreign adults). We enjoyed the place a lot because it lets you be quite close to the elephants. It's not every day that you see elephants being bathed in a river. In fact, there were more than 20. There were elephants of all sizes. Mainly for souvenirs. One of the shops was particularly interesting because they made products out of dried elephant dung. They had a little processing plant in the back of their shop.
Amazing place. Hundred of elephants. Was interest to see how they are taking the bath. And feeding is the main attraction.

I thoroughly enjoyed my time at the orphanage. It was a positive experience and seeing the elephants enjoy themselves, both in the park and in the river, I wondered how anyone could find fault with the place.

This time we visit was 4 of Us and 2nd visit for my daughter and first for the Son.. The place is so quiet and peaceful with very few local visitors..Best time to visit the place is now..kids enjoyed the elephant shower...
Must visit attraction in Sri Lanka...it is the place where you can feed ,bath and play with elephants ....must must visit

We did not actually go into the actual orphanage but merely paid (the full admission price) and watched them crossing the road and bathing at the bottom. Yes, the bull elephants were chained I guess for their and my safety. These were big animals that you would not wish to charge you. The younger and better behaved marched down the road and seemed well looked after and showed no discomfort that I could see. Although I feel that I only got to see just a glimpse of how the elephants are being treated, it was nice to see them bathing under the sun without any chains. If this institution is doing what they're saying, I hope they continue to do so and save as many elephants as possibile. Also, it's nice to see that the their PR Manager makes an effort to reply to most of the reviews on this page.

Visited on 17th Feb 2020 Entry Fee : SLR 800/- per Adult and SLR 400/- per Child of SAARC countries Timing : 8.30am till 5.30pm (ticket window closes) Ideal time to visit are 10.00am or 2.00pm respectively when the Elephant herds are taken for bathing to the river in batches, and 12.00noon or 4.00pm when teh elephant herds are brought back after bathing. We got a chance to see the Elephant herds being brought back from bathing and the walking of the herd in the sandy path is amazing. Watch towers and pathways are created in the venue for proper movements of the tourists. Also few installations and information boards are provided to inform all about the history of the place and its evolution through years. It also talks about the mahouts or elephant keepers and tools used by them to control the pachyderms. Duration of visit will be about 1 hour. Laksala and souvenir shop is available at this attraction. Outside the attraction there are few small shops selling fresh cut fruits and cold drinks and snacks. It can be hot on sunny day so please carry umbrella or caps. Go and Enjoy!

Up close and personal with he elephants, my wife was absolutely star struck with them and had the time of her life, some were chained when in certain areas but plenty roaming free, walked down to the river for play time and bath time and did not see any bad handling of them. feeding the elephants was a treat and the price of a basket of food very reasonable. well worth the visit

I'm not too sure what I thought about this place.  The elephants have been 'rescued' and they appear happy enough but I had the vague feeling thye were like peforming elephants in a zoo.  It is a geat expeirence to being down a thoroughfre and suddenly a small herd of elephants (with their handlers) wlk past you.  It was great too to see them behaving quite natrally in the water. I did see a family forking out a few thousand rupees to one of them so watch out for it.

At the moment, feeding of the orphaned elephants has been stopped, which detracts from the overall visit. Bathing of the elephants is still taking place but the water level in the river is currently very low.
All looks wonderful, but Mahouts have bull hooks and they use them.... they have no respect for the elephants.

We visited the elephant orphanage as a part of our srilankan trip. It was nice to see the elephants. The kids loved it. There are also activities that one can do over here, like feeding the elephants and accompanying them to the bath place. Our timings did not suit these activities and hence we missed it. Big number of elephants that you can observe all their daily activities in a natural habitat The elephants are taken to the river twice daily for bathing for 2 hours each time. The fees is 3000 rupies per person

must see for all Elephant lovers. Breathtaking watching these beautiful  creatures in a natural environment.

I visited Pinnawala Elephant Orphanage on 15 February 2020 from Australia. This was my first holiday to Sri Lanka even though my parents are Sri Lankan. I had heard many stories from my relatives about the elephants at Pinnawala and had always wanted to visit. In saying that, making the decision to go was a tough one as I am aware that currently Pinnawala is classed as ‚Äòslightly controversial‚Äô & I am an extreme animal lover! My honest opinion was that I was pleasantly surprised and I believe that they are genuinely trying to improve the operations of the park. Out of the 90 odd elephants I saw there, the majority were free roaming and appeared to enjoy their free time and bathing in the river. The only elephants I saw had chains were some of the males which is more for everyone‚Äôs protection so as not to cause a stampede. There were also 2 that were in pens apparently under veterinary care. The only ‚Äútourist‚Äù interaction that I saw was the fruit feeding which I avidly took part in - i bought like 4 baskets of fruit to give to 2 beautiful elephants. (**And for those people complaining about having to pay for the fruit baskets- get over it! It only costs like $2 aud for a basket of fruit! No tourists (that I saw) were allowed to bathe with the elephants etc at the park and I didn‚Äôt really see any ‚Äúexploitation‚Äù as such. Ie, I did not see any elephant rides being provided. It was just a joy to see them down at the river with many elephants enjoying the water or their mud bath. At the end of the day people will need to make up their own minds as to what they‚Äôre comfortable with. I personally am happy I went there and I don‚Äôt believe it is as bad as some people are making it out to be.

we spent a happy hour watching the elephants feed, scratch themselves on huge posts and then amble down to the river for a thorough brushing from their Mahoots . the look of sheer bliss on their faces was really amazing .

A lovely day watching the Elephants playing. We only saw 1 elephant chained and apparently he was being aggressive. Others were having a great time. They have a small museum where they re cycle the dung to make paper etc....I didn't want to go at first but I'm glad i did.

As the animals got used to the jeeps they don‚Äôt escape ‚Äì we had to stop few times to let elephants, warans, lizards cross the dirt road in peace.
you will fall in love with this place, Enjoy the place where elephants can roam freely without harming anyone

Never go to this elephants torture!!! Some elephants was chained to keep them still laying under the water for 1h only that some tourists can take pictures with them and ‚Äúwash‚Äù them. Also workers all the time was yelling and pushing elephants. Only bad experience

Pinnawala Elephant Orphanage is an orphanage and breeding sanctuary for rescued, injured or abused wild elephants which is situated northwest of the town of Kegalle, Sri Lanka. It shelters for over 88 orphaned elephants include about 15 baby elephants that volunteer can gain a wonderful opportunity with the largest land mammal on the earth. This institution caters not only for the abandoned babies but also for those injured and maimed within the jungle. We employ the expertise of both modern veterinary and traditional indigenous medical treatment to cater to these elephants needs. Orphanage provides all foods, medicines, milk for the baby elephants itself. It cost a lot. One elephant usually eats over 150 kilograms a day. Let me start by saying I have visited the Pinnewala Elephant Orphanage many times dating back to 1985. The spirit of the place has certainly changed and unfortunately I now cannot recommend this place to ethically or fair-minded tourists. I won‚Äôt comment on the treatment of the animals - there is a lot of info in other reviews about this. My main issue is the price - it costs approximately  $16.50 for a foreigner‚Äôs ticket. Bearing in mind that this is approximately what you would pay for an adult‚Äôs entry to a large, well-kept urban zoo with adequate facilities in Europe or the United States, the experience falls far short of that. There are far better ways to see elephants in Sri Lanka than to support this racket. Give it a miss and go to one of the national parks instead if you can.

I've been here multiple times since the 90s, & at the beginning, I was also not sure as to whether it was more of a tourist attraction than an actual sanctuary for orphaned or injured/sick elephants. Tourists were charged much more compared to locals & I kept asking myself where is that money going? Mahouts forced people to take pictures with the elephants & kept asking for tips. You would see them use bullhooks & sticks to hit the elephants. But after not visiting the place for more than a decade, I heard about a management change & changes happening at the place itself, so I wanted to see for myself if it was true. Yes, the costs for tourists is still much more than the locals. This won't be equal. South Asian countries pay lesser than the others. For the same price, all the tourists also get entrance to the Pinnawala zoo, which is about a 5min drive away. There are lots of more sheds/shelters built for the elephants to sleep in. They have much more roaming space inside the premises. There are boards & routes marked all over the premises. There are small shops for snacks/drinks as well as souvenirs. There are informational/educational boards. The employees can be easily recognised with their uniforms. You can watch the veterinarions treat some of the elephants. All of these things are new. Since 2012 I've been here 4 times & each time I've seen new, positive changes. Yes, I still sometimes see bulls chained. But they are for multiple different reasons. Some because they are in heat during mating period. Some because they are sick or injured. Some because of their temperament. Yes, I still see some mahouts offering to take pictures with the elephants for tips or using bullhooks/canes to discipline the elephants, but we as visitors should avoid taking pictures with the elephants & complain to the authorities if we see them mistreating the animals. I'm neither an elephant behaviourist nor a vet, but the establishment is getting better. It's certainly improving, BUT, there's room for improvement.

We ventured to this Orphanage on a ship's shore ex ... it's about a 2 - 2.5 hour drive from the port on a coach. I think if you can get here with a local guide you would be better off as you can spend as much or as little time as you like at the orphanage, whereas on a ship's tour the time is shorter. This orphanage is a government run orphanage and at least paying guests are aware of this when they enter and hopefully all money raised goes towards the elephant's upkeep and setting them free back into the jungle. I found all the public areas where we went and the enclosures we saw were very clean and tidy. Take Sri Lankan money with you - although you can use CC at the Orphanage shop and other shops in the town, generally speaking they don't take cash unless it's Sri Lankan money. There is an opportunity to feed the elephants by hand in one areas of the orphanage however Rupees are required - no USD or other currency and definitely no CC there !!  Luckily our guide exchanged some USD for Rupees but the fruit was gone very quickly. Yes there were a few elephants chained up in another enclosure but of the three enclosures we saw, this was the only one where they were chained.  The reason we were given for this was because they are wild animals... let's face it ... if they are males and are maturing, they could get annoyed about something and cause injuries to other elephants if not their handlers and / or the public if they crashed through the fence. Indeed at the elephant feeding area I saw one elephant get grumpy with another one for muscling in on the food I was feeding it - the elephant turned around and head butted the second elephant in its side to show it's displeasure at eating its food. The third area where we saw elephants at this Orphanage, the elephants were roaming free in a large treed area ... I wondered if this was the first stage of getting them used to fending for themselves before setting them free in the jungle. We had lunch included in our ship's shore excursion at a hotel by the river and luckily for us, they had quite a few elephants bathing there - a lovely thing to see. IMO, this excursion is not suitable for mobility impaired people because the terrain to get to the elephant enclosures is not paved and the surface is uneven.  There's also a few steps to negotiate within the elephant orphanage area.  Also, the "road" to the hotel where we went for lunch was not paved either.

I had read up about Pinnawala Elephant Orphanage before I visited Sri Lanka and from what I'd read, I was honestly considering skipping the visit due to claims of animal abuse and unnecessary confinement. But as it turned out, I was part of a group and because the group wanted to go, I had little option but to tag along. What I saw there truly horrified me. 1. Elephant calves were confined in a circular pen and their legs tied with metal chains that left little room for manoeuvre or free movement. 2. There was a tusker displaying a classic case of depressive symptoms - head swaying incessantly and bobbing up and down. Like the calves, he was also tied with a short metal chain in a small shed. 3. A herd of elephants we saw there was so scared of the keeper that as soon as he entered the enclosure with his bull-hook, the terrified elephants literally fled away from him. The keeper was careful not to display any aggressive behaviour in front of the tourists but it was obvious from how scared the elephants were, that terrible things go on behind the scenes. 4. While there, we saw a keeper repeatedly strike a pregnant elephant with a huge pole that had a metal spike at its end. He poked and struck her hard despite the presence of tourists there. I cannot imagine what must be going on once tourist hours are over. We then headed off to the river adjacent to the orphanage where they take the elephants for a bath - hoping that at least there, the elephants must be free. But they were not. Even here, the elephants were tied with short chains while tourists threw fruit at them. I would've compared Pinnawala Elephant Orphanage to a zoo but most zoos treat their animals better than this 'orphanage' does. Pinnawala is not a place I would ever visit again. My money isn't going into a place that has made a business out of abusing animals that should've been returned to the wild. Plus, they breed elephants in confinement at Pinnawala. Real orphanages don't typically do that. Instead, I would strongly recommend visiting the Elephant Transit Home near Udawalawe National Park. I haven't been there but from what I've heard, they are much more responsible in caring for orphaned elephants. Plus they return the elephants to the wild once they are old enough - unlike Pinnawala.
