You can watch the elephants bath in the local river. Once you look into the reason why and how, you need to make up your own mind on the scenario. I took up the option to wash the matriarch of the herd. She is a beautiful animal and I am thankful to get close and wash her, she made sure I was wet as well! Having been to other countries where orphaned animals are left to die, I am glad these gentle giants do have an option here. Yes, it is a tourist attraction, but feed needs to come from somewhere. (You can decide) If you are in the area I would go. BTW, we have travelling Sri Lanka very safe! There have been some great sites!

the orphanage is just a tourist attraction to make money. if you want to see elephants its best to ask your tour guide to take you to a national park were the elephants roam freely and you get to see them in their natural habitat.

This is not a orphanage!  It is a jail for elephants!  I have seen elephants in freedom and these poor animals are chained and terrified. I saw them when they were taken to their bath on the river. The poor animals were panicked by the instructors carrying sticks with hooks.  Just seeing the hooks the poor elephants turned away.  And once inside what they call the orphanage they had some of them chained by the front and back legs with clear symptoms of stress.  They kept moving from one side to the other.  Poor animals.  I can only denounce this barbarity since the facilities are of the government and are liars.  We thought it would be a good idea to see how they took care of elephants without parents and breastfeed them, but it's all a lie.  There are no orphaned elephants.  They have 63 specimens live worse than in a zoo.  I do not recommend it to anyone.  It is a shame to see elephants suffer in this way when they could live in freedom as I have seen in other parts of the country like in Arugam Bay.  They should close this place.  Tourist, do not contribute to the mistreatment of these poor animals.  The government profits at their expense.

It's lovely to see bunch of  \elephants so close. But everything here is almost too much touristic. Tickets are expensive. It is nice to see them while they are in the water. But it's a bit of a trap for tourist to steal from your pockets. People around here charged too much to take just one photo with an elephant.

Great experience and we can see more number of elephants at one single place. Baby elephants and female elephants are roaming freely and tourists can enjoy the site. We are informed that milk feeding is not there since elephants are now more than 5 years old. We can feed elephants (at specific timings ). Male elephants are kept separately. More than 10 elephants are moved to Kandy to participate in temple festival. Entrance fee (LKR 110) for local, SAARC countries (LKR 800) and other foreign countries (LKR 3000) are different.

great experience, by visiting the orphanage, you also sponsor the survival of the species! the best part of the visit are the bathing elephants in the river, we could have stayed there for hours! good tip from our tour guide: while watching the elephants at the river, enjoy a dring on the terrace at the right side of the river, it will give you access to an amazing and clear overview over the bathing elephants. Date of experience: August 2019

Not an elephant orphanage at all! More that 80 elephants in distress are kept there just to amuse the ‚Äúignorant‚Äù tourists. Most of the beast are chained and follow a routine programme just to entertain the crowd, so sad. all the time they are are being beaten and frightened to obey. It was nice to be near them but not pleasant to see all this circus.
If you love elephants this is the place. So many elephants in one place. You can feed them( at a particular time) and see them roam freely. Overall a fun park.
if you are travelling to dambulla or kandy you can visit this place in between. its very beautiful to see the baby elephants feed bottled milk and all the elephants having a bath in the river.

This place was not originally on our iternary  but our driver suggested it and it was on our way (almost) to Dambulla. I‚Äôm glad we stopped here. It is sad to see them in chains but this is a treatment centre for injured elephants. We got to feed Meenachi, the elephant. I should confess this is the first time I actually touched an elephant. After the feeding, the elephants were taken to a river across to bathe. How is elephants bathing in a river not a viral video on YouTube is beyond me. It‚Äôs was an absolute delight to watch these elephants frolic in the river. We couldn‚Äôt sit and watch for hours to keep up with our iternary. On our way out we stopped buy to pick-up Poo-poo paper. Yes it‚Äôs paper made out of elephant dung. Don‚Äôt worry it doesn‚Äôt smell. I suggest to bargain before buying or wait till Kandy to purchase. We found poo-poo paper cheaper in Galle (Dutch fort) and Kandy.

The concept of the areas (only) highlight is very weird! You really can't check in the hotels before 4 p.m. so you'll miss the elephants the day you arrive. If you just stay one night you have to check out at 12 a.m., so you can just see the elephants in the morning. The entrance fee to go to the river (and enter the only shopping street in town) is just as much as one night in the hotel (like 30$ for two)... Watching the elephants bathing is nice, but they are forced to go to the river twice a day. Some are tightly chained up and some are forced to go in the water or forced to lay down even though they obviousely don't want to. After they are putting an effort in covering themselves in mud and soil they are forced once again to gather under a huge "shower" and they get cleaned. Why? I don't get it! The keeper poke the elephants with sharp sticks with metal tips. They all looked healthy and not injured, but it all felt really wrong and not good. If you want to see the big animals just do a safari in Yala or Udawalawe. There you can enjoy wildlife without a bad concience!

We didnt find anything great there. Few activities around elephants. Kids might like it. Nothing much for adults. Tickets for SAARC COUNTRY is 800 lkr and golf cart is 1200 lkr Can be avoided definitely

This is first time we saw the Asian Elephants. We are scared first time when we saw them. We dont agreed hurting them. They need freedom we thing. But government doing good job keeping take care of them. There are some disabled. Tickets little bit expensive we think. there are big gap with local tickets. But its nice visit.

if you an elephant lover this is the best place to be to see the giants on the earth. My Kids love them. specially baby elephants. you can see how the baby elephants are fed milk during their feeding time live in this place. also you can see how they are having there daily bath in the river every day morning and afternoon. it is 100% safe place for kids too and they will enjoy it alot

DO NOT GO HERE! The place is a complete disgrace. i went with my family and this is no orphanage, it's a prison. We saw the men beating the elephants with sticks and prod them with the elephant hook FOR NO REASON AT ALL - one was minding his own business and eating and a man went and hit him with a stick as he walked past. We also heard them screaming in pain in the river when being prodded with the hooks. If I could have got away with it, I was genuinely close to taking the hook off the tiny man doing this and giving him the same treatment, I was absolutely furious. The elephants were scared stiff of the trainers, when they went near them with the hooks, they RAN away frightened. These animals are not roaming free in a park, they are being beaten and frightened to obey. Some had tears in their eyes and were swaying which is a sign of mental distress. They elephants in the enclosures were chained up and swaying with distress. One of the elephants tried to take a drink from a bucket of water - the man hit him with a stick and threw the bucket of water away. The trainers look and behave like criminals, they are absolutely disgusting, sadistic and are treating these poor animals so badly. DO NOT SUPPORT THIS PLACE.
Theres a big herd of elephants probably arround 100 and all are taken to river twice a day. That the best times to visit this wonderful place where you can see so many of this magnificent creature.

We went here wanting to make up our own minds from reading reviews and have very mixed feelings. On one hand, the elephants were healthy looking (no bones showing) and majority allowed to roam around the river free. However, around 8 elephants were chained to various spots around the river...the signs say this is to stop harm/danger of the Male elephants. From the looks of things, these elephants were chained for tourists photos as they were dotted around the hotel points and only need the front (of the viewing platform). The elephants are also clearly scared of the mahouts & when one of them began to ride the elephant he was nearly kicked off. We went up to the ‚Äòrelaxing zone‚Äô which didn‚Äôt look that way for the elephants at all. It sort of looks like an elephant zoo enclosure, however yet again all elephants there were chained up and visibly distressed. A better idea would be to let the elephants freely roam and invite tourists to visit safari style - no touching or contact. What we couldn‚Äôt understand is if this was an orphanage...why aren‚Äôt they let out into the wild, given they are well enough/old enough.

Lots of elephants were bathing in the river at the time when we arrived to this elephant orphanage and  there were few activities including elephant parade and feeding baby elephants. You are allowed to feed lovely, little cute baby elephants under their supervision which was great.
Our second visit to this orphanage, which has shrunk to just viewing elephants going down to the river for their daily dip!

The elephants are beaten up before the tourists arrive and chained up. Any place that allows elephants bathing and riding has had to beat them up at some point in life. The elephants do not actually live in the river but they are brought there every morning in a chain and beaten with a stick that gets into their skin for them not to move. It was horrible to see. Never go there.

Although seeing animals in captivity is never fun, but it seems like they take good care of the elephants in this sanctuary. When I arrived, the elephants were bathing in the river, which could be fun to watch. The interior of the sanctuary is not yet big and you may just spend less than an hour three

It was an awesome experience incomparable to other places I visit. All elephants small medium large were too cute to be true. It was a wonder to this close to the so called gentle giants of our universe. It was nature for me at its best.

Pinnawala Elephant Orphanage is an orphanage located at Pinnawala village approximately  13km from Kegalle town on the Colombo Kandy Road (A1 turn to left near the 82km post). This orphanage provides a lifeline to the orphaned baby elephants and orphaned elephants lost in the wilderness. You can see them having a bath in the river then crossed the road back to the orphanage where they are feed and roam the ground. The orphanage will be open from 08.30 hrs to 18.00 hrs daily. Normally herd of elephants bathing in the river from 10.00 to 12.00 again from 14.00 to 16.00. Milk feeding starts in morning 09.15, 13.15 and 17.00 hrs. It is the place that gives us unforgettable experience. Elephant caretakers must care with love and respect without being cruel to the elephants will help them grow up with nature.
Surely a memorable trip. Elephant feeding and bath. Kind of an Elephants parade as well. We missed the kids. They wouldve loved it.

I hadn't done any research on this place before visiting which was a huge mistake. The young elephants are tamed by being chained up and beaten and shouted at. They were visibly very distressed and making a lot of noise. I felt extremely upset when I saw this and angry at myself for visiting. Our guide then took us down to the river where the elephants are taken to bathe. Some are chained up and forced to lie down in the water. There is no need to treat these poor elephants this way. Go and visit Minneriya National Park instead to see happy elephants roaming free in the wild.

So disappointed with Pinnawala Elephant orphanage. They advertise saying elephants are ‚Äúsemi wild‚Äù but reality is, elephants are not well treated, elephants have mahouts to be trained and unfortunately they don‚Äôt have a proper semiwild life. Elephants will end working for temples and going to Parahera in some point which makes me really sad. Pinnawala orphanage says there are 84 elephants but visible you can only see a group of 27 elephants + other group of 10 sick elephants. Where are the others? I would say, chained, because they refuse to be domesticated* I paid 3k rupees for the entrance expecting to see elephants having a better care. I am the person who would pay more if elephants are well treated. Elephants only eat once per day (kindly note elephants of Pinnawala are well fitted), but still, the nature of elephants is to eat several times per day. Sri Lanka government, please do something to improve the programs for elephants, I understand your mindset, culture and religion and most important I respect it, I understand the value and meaning of Parahera, but don‚Äôt advertise lies. Please give a better care for them. Elephants are humble and loyal animals we should be better for them. *Note: some elephants are on their Musth period, is understandable that they remain separated from the group, but, are 50 elephants on their Musth? Don‚Äôt think so. Note 2: tourism is an income that Pinnawala orphanage needs to give elephants a better life. I won‚Äôt say don‚Äôt visit the place, I will say: go and see for yourself, raise the voice and ask Sri Lanka Government to improve the programs.
Elephants controlled by handlers. Disappointing for what you are expecting. Elephants seem sad and are visibly scared of their handlers.

This is an awsome place, one must visit while in Coorg or rather in Karnataka,,,, A sort of Island where these elephants are looed after was just too good! They were fed with hey balls that were wrapped around some seeds and cereals that were required by the animals. Oil was applied on their body to avoid any wounds. Their bathing was also very interesting in the river ... viewers are given a chance to take a pert in the activities. Most inmportantly, the animals were almost in the open and were very closed to the viewers. The only problem was the approach... the walk through the river was a  bit dangerous, as the path was slippery and many people were seen falling int he water and getting injured. There is no good arrangements for parking the vehicles also. This part must be looked after.

On the way to Kandy from Colombo take a visit to see the Elephants. If your timing is right you see them having a bath in the river then cross the road back to the orphanage where they are feed and roam the grounds They appear well cared for and are checked for illness and treated. A lot are injured or former working Elephants who retire there or orphans who need looking after. Having read the bad reviews I didn‚Äôt see any mistreatment and to me it looks like they were caring for the animals, the handlers do heard the elephants with sticks or a hand slap on the legs but it didn‚Äôt seem to bother them and the 4 or 5 tonne elephant has the size and weight advantage if it did hurt, they could easily kill the handler

We arrived in the late morning and found most of the elephants down at the river bathing.  As we walked down the street to see them, we passed several shops selling souvenirs and then suddenly were treated to a few elephants being ridden back to the orphanage from the river.  It was a bit scary, but also exciting as they walked right past us.  We got down to the river and there was the rest of the group bathing and playing.  We took a few pictures and then went to the orphanage where after a short walk inside we came to an area where one can feed the elephants.  I didn't see any mistreatment while we were there, but our experience was limited to about an hour and a half.  It's a long drive to get here, but if you like elephants, it's worth the drive.  We also passed a few wild elephants crossing the road on the way from Colombo, so keep an eye out if this is your route too.

Supposedly elephants roam naturally through the 24 acre park. Nope. Penned elephants trained to lay their trunks out so you can feed them fruit you have to buy. One can tell the elephants didn‚Äôt like their handlers. Nice to feed and touch elephants though

column6: Explore the Beauty of Sri Lanka
column11: Sri Lanka has about 5,500 wild elephants on the island. The Pinnawala Elephant Orphanage was founded in 1975 by the Sri Lanka Department of Wildlife Conservation. The orphanage is situated northeast of the town of Kegalle, halfway between Colombo and Kandy in the hills of central Sri Lanka. At Pinnawala, the elephants move freely in a herd within the area. They are fed at certain hours, which is when visitors can see them. Newborn baby elephants are fed with feeding bottles and around 3 times per day visitors can participate in the feeding. At 10.00 and 14.00 each day the elephants are walked to the river Maha Oya for a two-hour bath, where they play with each other in the water, which is really good fun to see.

I have mixed feelings about my visit to Pinnawala. Having read some disturbing reports I was nervous about what we would see. We visited early in the morning and saw the elephants bathing and then went back to the reserve and saw some elephant there in the enclosures. Did we see cruelty? No. Did we see chains? Yes. Was I impressed? I don't think so. Now, I have to confess to not being a fan of zoos on the whole but I can really appreciate a zoo that has a conservation ethos (Twycross for instance) Pinnawala felt like a poor zoo to me. A few elephants paraded for public entertainment. Thats ok I guess if there is a greater good but I'm not sure there is. Overall this was an ok experience but I wouldn't go again.

After reading reviews about the treatment of these elephants I was very anxious to see for myself. When we arrived early in the morning the elephants were having there feed and the keepers cleaning out the poo and water troughs and refilling them, they were all playing around and having such fun, not one elephant was pacing up and down or looked stressed, one elephant was spraying the keeper with water whilst he was trying to clean out the trough, after about 1/2 hour of watching these beautiful animals, they were let out and started walking down the road to the river the traffic is stopped whilst they cross the road it was so lovely to see them being washed and playing in the river spraying water over each other this happens twice a day, whilst we were we had the opportunity to feed a elephant with some fruit which was amazing and we really enjoyed this and so did the elephants. The bull elephants were chained on the way to the river for safety, these male elephants are enormous about 8feet high and its a way of controlling them whilst going down to the river, we looked at there feet there was no sores cuts or callous the male and females are separated when they go down the river because the males can get very aggressive at no point did we see any keepers use sticks on the elephants, we had a lovely time and glad we went, at least being at this place they are not poached and left to die.

My interests are elephant bathing in the river,baby elephants milk and fruit feeding, very interesting to visit the orphange,safe at all,but feel sad sometimes because elephants are chained,no freedom as wild elephants but we had 2-3 hr fun time with elephants,specially baby elephants are cute, very interesting on the way to Kandy

I visited Pinnawala Elephant Orphanage just over a week ago and I must say that I was on high alert after a few derogatory articles I had seen written about the facility and its treatment of the elephants. Happily, I found nothing worthy of a complaint. The elephants parade down to the river and anyone who knows animals can see that they are intelligent beings who are used to the routine and are not at all stressed by the watching crowds - in fact, some clearly loved it and were happy to participate and be patted or fed a morsel along the way.  Once in the river they splash, roll around in the water and clearly enjoy themselves. Yes, some did have a loose chain around their necks, but this didn't bother them. When you consider the size of an elephant and the general havoc they could cause to a community when aggressive, it's not difficult to understand that there are times when they must be prudently restrained or separated. As for returning them all to the wild; these elephants no longer have a place in the wild as they have formed new family bonds within their new herd. Many have already been rescued from the wild where they were close to death and others are on medication or special food. So if you want to truly help elephants and not just have a pompous rant about turning them loose, visit Pinnawala, spend a few dollars towards their support and watch them happily splash about in safety.

Make sure you check before hand when the timings are for the feeding and the washing - there is a great restaurant for food from where you can watch the elephants being brought down to the river for their washing... the elephants love it - they roll around in the river, some are eating, some just standing enjoying the coolness of the running river water. The babies are there too all being cared for by the elephant controllers (!) They now have a big hose like a fire hydrant that they use to soak the elephants too and the keepers also go and wash them down with brushes. A great photo opportunity that then you can walk back up with them to the orphanage as they put them back into their fields and areas... a great day out for all.

the Elephant Orphanage is such an interesting place to visit.  At certain times the elephants (ages 1 to 5 years) are fed.  There are viewing stands so you can watch while the elephants are given milk and also greens to eat.

Long drive from Colombo, but you will not regret it when you get there. Try to reach early to see the elephants taking their bath. You will get the opportunity to ride or feed one. Thrilling experience just to be near to watch them move freely and safely.

Expensive at 3,000 rupees. Locals pay just 110 rupees. I'm happy to pay more as a foreign tourist but not 30 times more. There is no guide nor any information. You can see an elephant chained up swaying from side to side up close. You can see 20 odd elephants in an open area about 30m away. That's it. Very ordinary. 2 stars only because you can go across the road and see some elephants bath in the river and then walk back up to the orphanage. They walk straight past you and across the road. Pretty cool. The traffic is stopped by the police each time. I think you need the ticket to get to the river, our driver organized that. Overall pretty poor. Save your money and time.

These Huge but loving animals keep you amazed through out your visit to this orphange. Don t miss the elephant bathing experience you will left in awe expression. Here they allow you to feed the elephants.

Reviews of Pinnawala Elephant Orphanage praise and condemn so our only choice was to see it for ourselves. The stamp of the country‚Äôs Department of Wildlife Conservation on the park was the deciding factor. Over a twenty year period, Pinnawala Elephant Orphanage hand raised abandoned babies, treated the injured and integrated displaced elephants into a growing herd. Currently, 88 elephants are part of the Pinnawala family on their 30-acre property, making it one of Sri Lanka‚Äôs largest tourist attractions. At Pinnawala Elephant Orphanage you will see chains. This is precautionary for large males while bathing, wandering the park ‚Äì river path, and when a female‚Äôs seductive pheromones spike. A full grown male can stand more than 2.5 metres weighing  5.5 tonnes. A force to be reckoned with when they want to get down to business. You will also see mahouts rounding the elephants to keep them in one spot. This is also precautionary to keep them from getting too close to punters. A disappointing observation was people paying some entrepreneurial mahouts to bathe the elephants. The elephant is chained and made to lie on its side during the encounter. This is not approved and is something the orphanage is trying to eliminate. Elephants eat an average of 250kg of food per day, multiply that by 88 of them and you have an expensive grocery bill. Modern veterinary equipment and traditional indigenous medicine come at a price and the gallons of milk required to raise a baby elephant is also exorbitant. Sponsorship programs, donations and your ticket price all contribute to the cost of feeding and caring for these adorable creatures. Pinnawala Elephant Orphanage is not perfect, but the care for these elephants is obvious. This is a heavily tourist-trafficked attraction. Vendors take advantage of the captive audience and sell everything from elephant poo paper products (quite an interesting process) to every form of elephant printed clothing you can imagine. Away from this retail madness, however, is picturesque countryside, a meandering river and comfortable accommodation.
Elephants are chained up and poked with sticks. Do yourself a favour and visit the open elephant safari where they roam free.
I loved every bit of this place. You need to spend at least 2-3 hours in this place and play with the elephants.

Having read some of the reviews on here I approached this visit with caution. But I was pleasantly surprised. Sure, it no longer operates as an orphanage but a controlled breeding ‚Äòzoo.‚Äô That said, the elephants seemed well cared for and minimally managed by the mahouts. I never saw any being mistreated. Yes some are temporarily chained for the safety of the herd and human safety. So long as they control the matriarch and/or bull the rest will generally follow. It‚Äôs easy to judge but the govt agency has a big elephant population to manage throughout the country with very little funding, all in various states, wild & working, and in different relationships with humans.

me and my family members visited the place,attractive place with tame elephants,elephant bathing in the river and their milk and fruit feeding time were my favourite events baby elephants seems cute and lovely some elephants are chained and  felt very sad about their freedom, but anyway good place to visit,specially with kids

The orphanage is located in Pinnawala town, near Kandy. It took us by car 2:30 hrs. The orphanage is huge and you can see loads of elephants in land being look after eating and walking. Then you can go to see them bath along the river and is just wonderful. Breath taking to be in contact with these huge animals, kids can come close to them touch them and help to bath them a life time experience.

It was really nice to visit this place as we love elephants. Time of bathing and feeding was nice. But of course it is not good to see the bad behavior to them . I heard a lot of bad thing about this place but i did not see something bad.

Wonderful experience. I fed the elephants which costs 250 rupees a plate of fruit pieces. Entrance ticket about 800 if SAARC country and 750 to wash the elephant. But worth it. Up close to see and touch n feed the animal! Loved it.

Its a nice place. The sight of elephants bathing is cute and something children will surely enjoy. The elephants march past the entire road with keepers and go into the river. There are restaurants along side the river where you can eat and watch these elephants bathing. Bathing timings are 10am to 12pm and 2-4pm.

Watching these beautiful animals enjoying the river and then walking up the shopping street back to their home is just a lovely experience. The orphanage is a fantastic achievement supporting these orphans - now of all ages. You have the chance to feed them as well and we would certainly recommend that you do not miss this on your travels.

This orphanage is amazing. It supports the weaker elephants in the Jungle. It seems the mothers bring their young to be given milk and we watch them been let in through  the gates to be fed. There was even an old elephant with a prosthetic boot.....really heartwarming.

We stoped at this popular location with our two little ones 7 and 9. The place has changed since our last visit. We were sad to here that the elephant who had his heel blown by a land-mine   as calf after 14 years had passed away a year back. They don‚Äôt have calf‚Äôs so milk feeding was not possible and only one elephant could be fed.  They children enjoyed watching the elephants and wanted to know if these elephant will leave this orphanage. All in all it was good experience for the kids.

I strongly recommend skipping this experience. There are so many great opportunities to see elephants in their natural habitat in Sri Lanka. This was not an orphanage, more like a zoo. The staff did not appear to care about the animals. The animals are not treated well. They don‚Äôt seem to have the freedom to roam that I hoped they would. They are chained up at times. Standing in the river, they were made to stand in a tight group. The website advertises bottle feeding but this is no longer happening. We were approached by an employee who offered to take a photo. He then led us behind a building (we thought he was leading us to more elephants) and demanded a tip. Our kids did enjoy feeding fruit to the elephants. Still, not the experience we were hoping for.

We were grossly disappointed to see elephants in chains, many of them visibly distressed, forced to pose for tourists. It felt like a zoo/circus. Don't do the same mistake as we did and don't financially support this animal hell. However when we visited I was sad to see these poor animals in such distress. Better Avoid.

If you want to see elephants in their natural habitat, this is not the place for you. If you want to get up close and personal to elephants who are being well taken care of, come here. Yes, some of the (male) elephants are in chains but you leash your dog, right? Same concept only you're trying to leash a 2-ton semi-wild animal.  I never saw one hit or its chain pulled on. They seemed to listen well to voice commands. Elephants were in social groups. Was fun to see them walking through the street from the river back to the sanctuary.  Got to feed one. Loved it.

The whole concept, location, facilities  are fabulous and fantastic. Best such in the world! Been to many such facilities around the world, nothing comes even close when it comes to being close to the Indian elephants.!

Having been to an Elephant sanctuary in Phuket, Thailand where the elephants were free to roam and were very well looked after, this was a considerable disappointment. Elephants penned in and chained by the neck and feet is what you can expect to see here. Added to this, the wardens hold long spear like ‚Äòtools‚Äô with curved ends in order to ‚Äòcontrol‚Äô the animals, this creates a very circus-esque atmosphere where you just feel sorry these beautiful animals. Bottle feeding is advertised but was not happening on our day of visit - don‚Äôt get too excited, you yourself don‚Äôt get to bottle feed elephants as the orphanage implies, you watch an employee do it (just to save you some time). All in all, save your money and pay more elsewhere for a more natural, less ‚Äòzoo-like‚Äô experience where the elephants are treated better. T

There was huge property where raising up, taking care and protecting Elephants, but i think they did not run it properly. There was nothing to do except for going around in the bright sun-meeting elephan randomly , feeding them and taking pics with them. No shows, no entertainment at all...

I imagine that Pinnawala Elephant Orphanage is a haven for elephants who can no longer live in the wild. However, I found the experience more like a circus show where the elephants are paraded for us to see them "bathed" (some chained), then marched back home after the show. The caretakers may be very caring but hard to tell given the touristy nature of the sight,

Elephants chained, many of them visibly distressed, forced to pose for tourists. The 'orphanage' staff is treating them in most abusive way. Don't do the same mistake as we did and don't financially support this animal hell.

column7: The Royal Town of Sutton Coldfield, UK
column11: We visited this tour part of what Mercury Holidays offer, I did at the time question the rep about the chains on the  elephannts as I had read about this, and aware this is a cultural difference, but at the end of the day it should be about the elephant not a zoo or making the elephant perform for you.  The Rep advised the chains were required as the Bulls do get aggressive.  What I don‚Äôt understand is elephants should be able to roam freely, however when we visited I was sad to see these poor animals in such distress. When you approach the orphanage you are advised not to purchase any fruit but to buy inside, the place was heaving with local school children coach loads - not sure if this is part of their school curriculum but vast amount visiting.  The elephants in the watering hole seemed dazed and when one elephant approach the handler who has a stick with a hook to control the elephants came close she quickly reacted and walked away - the elephants seemed lifeless and bored.  One elephant was showing signs of distress side to side shaking her head and body - not nice to see.  We then visited the feeding stations and walked passed where the elephants are seen my the public - makes you wonder how much space do these elephants have to roam - not a great deal.  I saw the bull elephants chained and what was so shocking was the behaviour again rocking back and forth - this is where he remains all day - and the phrase for the wealth and safety of all elephants was the reason - this was utterly sad, such a beautiful animal chained. Again aware the cultural differences but, somehow human instinct should kick in for anyone to see these elephants are anything but happy. We then visited the feeding station once again for the elephants to perform - one of the man handlers asked if I wanted a picture of the elephant raising its trunk - he called the elephant over and used this stick to control her - just like a circus act, and she had chains around her neck. Please think twice about contributing to this orphanage in hindsight I regret contributing, and my advice would be be go on the safari - this is where you see elephants roaming freely and happy but the choice is yours.

This is the best place to view elephants close to you.  You can shop the many stores, eat and view the elephants as they parade them down the main street.  It's a sight you wont soon forget.  You can actually feed and bathe them too.

We visited this place on our way to Kandy. The price of Rs3000 is way to much to see some elephants bathing in the river. And when you visit the otherside, the park where they stay, there is not much to see. I do understand you have to chain these semi wild animals but I really thought they will roam around freely. It is nice to see them thaking a bath i  the river and then walk over the street back to the park. I have to admit that it is not worth the price.

Spent 2 hours at Millennium Elephant orphanage. The pre walk information sessions was really informative and revealing!  Walked with the first elephant born there "Rani" - just a wonderful experience as she accepted food and gently walked around with us. Her mahout was gentle and you could see the intense relationship. The helped washed her in the stream and scrubbed her with coconut shell.  I swear she winked at me!  She lay there as we all had turns. Then she showered us with water from her trunk. These are just beautiful and serene creatures. Next door is the only elephant poo paper factory in the world. It's free and fascinating how the elephant dung is used to make paper in a very simple and environmentally friendly way. Nice gift shop as well with the final products for sale, all reasonably priced.

I was dubious about this tour seeing some of the reviews. But I saw no evidence of any cruelty. The elephants are taken to the river twice a day and seem to enjoy their swim. Yes the bulls wear chains but are not chined up they wear them so that they can be controlled if necessary. The attendants are very caring and happy to go into the paddock should an elephant become nasty but never used sticks only their voices to separate the two ladies who seemed to have an issue. I‚Äôm very glad I did this tour and would recommend Asda tours who provided a great experience

While going from Colombo, the tour operators have this on their itinerary.Only Sri Lankan currency accepted for purchasing the tickets. Elephants can be seen chained, eating leaves, taking a bath.In case one has already seen elephants, the trip is not worth the effort. Better is to go straight from Colombo to Kandy

We went to this place to see some elephants of the orphanage which are there like 60-70. They have specifc time to take them to bath to the river. Ticket for 1 person is Rs 3000 which is quite expensive. Nice to visit for a shot time.
Never visit this place. The elephants are chained and the jailors have elephantspears and hitting them. Only for making money, has nothing to do with an orphanage

The elephants were lovely but I hated seeing them in chains Have visited an orphanage in Kenya and there were no chains I realise the male elephants can be aggressive but wondered why they have not been released to the wild again also they let them breed? Site is attractive lovely by the river watching the elephants until you see the chains Had meal in restaurant and it was very good personally I would not visit again but maybe our attitudes are different to theirs

I went there with my family.entrance fee is a very cheap .there is more than 60 elephants.and more baby elephant also.it was so enjoy full during they are bathing time.they are fully enjoyed. some of the elephants need to be chained because they can be dangerous.Great entertainment for the whole family.

If you short of time and/or money, you can easily avoid this place. This is basically a zoo (even worse than a zoo) than an orphanage. How often do you see children in orphanage tied up with chains and made to walk a long alleyway just so that a few tourists who paid exorbitant prices for tickets can watch them walk and feed them coconuts? The elephants take bath in the pond which is at the opposite side of the road from the orphanage, twice a day. We were very excited that we reached just in time when the elephants were getting ready to walk through that alley to go to the pond to take bath. What we saw was very disappointing. Almost all the elephants were chained to their teeth. Most of them were missing their tusks (don't know when it happened) and almost all of them just sat in the pond and did nothing. Inside the orphanage, it was the same story. You can see them grazing or can give them bananas or other fruits (there are extra charges for that as you can only buy the fruits from one of the shops inside the orphanage). We were from the SAARC country so we paid 750 LKR per person for entry but I think for foreign tourists from other countries the fees is around 3000 LKR. It is highly overpriced and it's better to actually go to Marissa and watch whales in their natural habitat instead of seeing chained Elephants sitting in water. You can do all the things you can do here at Dehiwala zoo in Colombo, including seeing Elephants taking bath.

We visited this place in February as part of a tour with Mercury Holidays.  We were hoping it would be the highlight of our trip, sadly it left us with bad memories for this part of the trip. We started watching the elephants in the water from an adjacent hotel veranda, the elephants certainly didn't appear to want to be there, they were corralled to stay close to the hotels so that visitors could see them.  We then went to the land site on the opposite side of the road, again elephants are corralled for the entertainment of the viewing public. A very heavily pregnant elephant was trying to get to a water hole at the top of the paddock with some other elephants following, however the mahouts would not let her rest and drove her and her followers to the part of the paddock closest to the tourists.  In another part of the paddock one of the mahouts was repeatedly hitting an elephant in the leg making it squeal, a sound I don't want to hear again.  One of the staff stood near me kept saying 'happy elephant'. I'm not David Attenborough but I would say that the elephant was not squealing with delight.  There were also other elephants under shelter which clearly had mental issues and were heavily chained, I do however appreciate that where they have been rescued from may be the cause of their problems and not the place they have come to. I have read through some of the reviews and they do vary widely and of course they're all personal assessments, some cultures approach animal care differently, for instance some have referred to being able to ride the elephants which I personally don't agree with.  I would strongly recommend you think seriously about visiting this place, yes there are a lot of elephants here which is great, but the evident lack of care for them is distressing if you are an animal lover.

A must visit if you like elephants, there must be around 50. From the age of around 2 months old, they get released in pairs from the main pound towards the milking station, it‚Äôs fantastic to see them realise there‚Äôs food, and it‚Äôs a race. It‚Äôs a vey cheap entrance fee, around 500 slr which is approx ¬£2.50. But get there early as it gets packed. Great entertainment for the whole family. They are well looked after.

Despite all the positive recommendations for this elephant 'orphanage', it seemed more like an elephant medium security prison. There are many captive elephants that are kept in large fields. In some areas the visitors can come close and even touch the tamer elephants. Around mid morning (10:30 to be precise), the elephants are paraded down to  the nearby river and encouraged (or in the case of some of the young male bulls, forced) to bathe. The male elephants are chained up and pushed and prodded, and appear and sound unhappy. The females and children though are allowed to roam and appear less anxious. In comparison to elephant sanctuaries in Thailand or free roaming African elephants, many of these Asian elephants appeared to be distinctly unhappy and uncomfortable. We went with two teenage girls and they were distinctly unhappy with the elephants' circumstances, as was I.

This place has alot of elephants which range in age. They also offer you to ride on one of them.. There was a baby elephant who was dancing for us..it was lovely! There are separate entry tickets according to your prefrence..we took the 3000/-  SL rupees pre person ticket for half hour!

My family and I arrived in Sri Lanka last morning. it was sunny and hot without air pollution, we met our guide Yohan and he led us to our hotel to settle down. he is the local people who had healthy black skin and big mouth and ears, he was not that handsome but looked smart. I found he is a kind, helpful and outgoing man, although he's English accent is not very standard. On the road to an elephant base, my mother told me it's a rescue base for the hurt elephants. Along the road, we saw many different kinds of trees and sometimes there are small lizards appeared suddenly.   Along the road, we saw many different kinds of trees and sometimes there are small lizards appear suddenly After we arrived, Yohan suggested us to gave one of the elephants a bath, at first I was scared to touch him, he looks so big and powerful, but he just stayed there and playing water adorably, so I began to approach him step by step, I held up my brush, the movie slowly left and right. when I found it's not hard at all. then we went to ride and feed them. my mom felt scared, she couldn't even get off the elephants back by herself and refused to give them food and everyone laughed. By the way, the food is ready great there, especially the seafood including fish crabs and shells. I really enjoyed my trip this time and I believe you'll love everything when you are here.

we visited on our way to kandy.we did colombo city tour on arrival in the morning so reached there late afternoon-bathing time at the river.to make most of it,you need to be there in the morning,but we had limited time on the tour.good sovenier shops.few hours is enough.

Pinnawala Elephant Orphanage is known to have the largest herd of captive elephants in the world. Established in 1975, this also functions as a breeding ground in addition to its initial goal of providing care for orphaned baby elephants. Visitors are able to take part in certain events such as milk feeding, fruit feeding, and also witness bathing.

It is definitely one of the best experiences in Sri Lanka. I personally love elephants, and it is so nice to see them have a shelter and people who care about them, it was a lot of fun to watch them walk by us, to see them enjoy a bath in the river, and there is always a naughty one in the group. you should go and experience it for yourself, every ticket counts for those elephant orphans.

You cannot view this with western eyes, some of the elephants need to be chained because they can be dangerous. The alternative would be to put the elephant down. These are orphan animals that are being prepared to be released to the wild at Yala It is a wonderful sight to see these magnificent animals bathing in the river.

Horrible place.  They say it's an orphanage helping elephants but how can it be a pleasant life for an elephant being chained up all day.  They look stressed swinging from side to side.  I left crying for these poor souls that are suffering everyday. There are better alternatives helping them than treating them like that.

I know they explain why they chain elephants, but it‚Äôs always hard to see elephant chained and think it‚Äôs for their own good - at an orphanage at that. Then, the price to go in and see the elephants is just ridiculous when all you get is to walkthrough shops, sit a restaurants, and watch the elephants from a distance. On the other side you have to buy the food if you want to feed them. I mean, it was a waste of my time. I had a better experience with elephants in Thailand. If you had never seen elephants, I would just wait around the area because they walk them from one side to the other - take your picture and keep it moving. Oh and if you had s driver like me, they will take you to an Herb Garden as ‚Äúpart of the ticket price‚Äù to get a tour: TOTAL SCAM. Go for the tour, but don‚Äôt buy anything.

We were a bit disturbed that the first elephants were chained up! We were told that the animals were a bit "frisky" and needed protection from each other. Perhaps we were overly sentimental but it just didn't seem right. The elephants cooling down in the river was good to watch. We eat in the Elephant Bay Restaurant and the food was terrible. Worst we have had on our trip.
Beautiful place and encounter with well kept and happy ELephant. kids can feed them and see them bath happily in a river.

I found this place distressing. So many of the elephants were chained up and swaying from side to side. I think the whole 'orphanage' title is questionable.I witnessed some of the kahoots hooking and poking the elephants alot. One kahoots wouldn't stop poking and hooking his elephant and when he walked away the elephant went crazy trying to break her chains. It was terrible to watch. I wish I never went there.

This was an interesting experience with many elephants roaming unchained. It was good to see them in that environment, however there were also a number of chained elephants that looked quite forelorn. I expect there is a good reason but it seemed unfortunate. There was also feeding of the elephants by tourists and both parties clearly liked it. There was washing in the river which the elephants seem to like - some of the elephants received a body scrub by the handlers. We also did a seperate elephant safari in the wild and it was much better to see the elephants roaming free.

We visited this elephant orphanage and quite honestly didn't see any ill treatment of the animals.  It was lovely to see the elephants walking to the river for  a bathe. We got quite close to a few of the cheeky ones who came up to the chain where we could stand. Yes a few of the males have a chain to a leg but we were told they were the "frisky" ones and it was to help keep them under control. The older  males are separated from the females as in the wild . They even have a "murderer" male which is kept apart from all the others and needs a few members of staff around when cleaning his area. He apparently has killed humans when he was in the wildlife reserves-  so nice to see he has been given a chance to life as his rages were probably instigated by humans  who didn't behave appropriately around him. We were told not to buy fruit from the street sellers and were always reminded to behave appropriately. Such a joy to see these huge creatures.

Some negative reviews on here and comments concerning the treatment of the elephants. Some are in chains but these are male elephants and are to control their natural aggression to other males. The mahmood‚Äôs use sticks to encourage understanding of commands - again for the safety of the elephants and surrounding people. They use the sticks to apply pressure to vital points ( acupuncture points) which do not harm the elephants - if you‚Äôve ever been struck in a pressure point you will know a slight jab doesn‚Äôt hurt but does encourage the body to move in a certain way. This is what they do with the Sticks. You couldn‚Äôt move an elephant with a shove or a little stick otherwise. If you‚Äôre concerned with the treatment suggest research first before judging. Many of the elephants come from farmland where they‚Äôve been trapped in holes dug by farmers to collect water. They often have broken limbs when they come to the sanctuary. Once recovered, most are returned to the forests. Some pictures attached of the time we watched them bathing. One thing to note - from wherever you are you will likely take some time to get there. For us it was worth the journey.

If the tourists help pay for their food it is ethically OK(ish). It was great to get close to the elephants, from a cafe, and the vast majority of elephants were free to wander. Three were chained and one looked unhappy. Some seemed to really enjoy their back scrubs and it was a memorable experience. There were a series of shops on the way down and one tried to shortchange us 1000 rupees so be careful.
Time your visit to see them either go down the road to the watering hole or back up!!! You can feed them and bath them all for extra cost!!

I understood from all the material that this place is an elephant orphanage where they take care of motherless elephants. But it is only one big tourist show and the animals are not treated well but moved around by a group of attendants with sharp sticks that they use to poke the elephants. The elephants are obviously scared of the sticks and try to move away only to be stuck by another attendant from the back. Horrible to watch and all done so we tourists can get the best photo opportunity. A huge part of the park is closed or under construction but no one tells you about that. Price for foreigners are 3000
Great visit to see elephant rescued. No shop for merchandise which is good to see. Watched herd down at river and walking pack to park.

Only 5% of the park is open and no one is informing tourists. They still charge 3000 rupees per person, however you cant see all of the park. I visited this park 2 times already and I know how big is it, also you can see it in the map. We asked staff to call us a manager however we waited for more then 2 hours and no one showed up. Staff doesn‚Äôt know how to deal with tourists and they overcharging everyone who doesn‚Äôt know how the park should look like. While waiting for the manager we talk with the staff and we heard few different stories why we couldn‚Äôt see the park: 1. 95% of the park is closed for the refurbishment 2. They have untained elephants and at the moment is too dangerous 3. You can see all park only after 4pm HOWEVER no one informing tourists about it and still charging FULL price. We wasted half of our day here just trying to talk with the manager who first was having the lunch and after disappeared for the conference. So at the end of the day we didn‚Äôt waste more our time and just left. But for everyone i would just say dont go to this place because it‚Äôs not worthy!!!

95% of the parn is closed and construction works  going on . No one informed us before we purchased the tickets . They just charge  Rs 3000 to just a walk 5 min in the park . Not worth the price . It's better to go to millennium park in pinnawala and see elephant and ride them feed them for same money you wasted in pinnawala.
A must see and the showers of the elephants are super. Check the timing of the showers because its not done through the whole day.

We visited the orphanage on the way round to Dambulla. We had read reviews on tripadvisor but we were undecided whether to visit. In the end we felt that perhaps our entrance fee would contribute to the elephant upkeep so we proceeded to visit. On arrival and purchase of tickets we were taken down a small shopping street opposite to the orphanage which takes you to the river where the elephants bathe daily. We arrived to see at least 30 elephants enjoying the water with some "snorkelling" and a couple of younger ones being a little cheeky. This part of the visit was great. We did not wait to see all the elephants make their way back past the shops and street stalls but that might have been fun. Back at the orphanage the pens, albeit large, just did not offer any stimulation for the elephants. Even though they are trying to make improvements the orphanage itself was not what we expected or would like to consider as acceptable for keeping what are wild elephants. We were saddened by what we saw and it left us thinking why not take them to one of the national parks and releasing them back to the wild. Probably not that simple but thats how it left us feeling.

You feel being hooked in a tourist trap. they charge a lot for nothing. it is just a so-called orphanage but nothing more than some captured and chained elephants. it also makes you sad and angry. because they misuse elephants and behave badly with them. don't spend a penny here. I think some organization should do something to close the place in the name of animals rights.

A little uncomfortable to see a few of the elephants in chains although we were informed this was due to their unruly adolescent behaviour. This is very much a tourist destination rather than a pure sanctuary. For all the perceived negatives the elephants are well cared for and it is a wonderful sight to see them making the journey down the road to the river for bathing which the elephants do seem to genuinely enjoy.

The elephants (there are around 80 at the orphanage) are taken to the nearby river in groups of 10 throughout the day. It's a  privilege to see them making their way past local businesses to and from the river. And of course to see them frolic and play in the water.

We were grossly disappointed to see elephants in chains! It felt like a zoo/circus. The elephants didn't know what to do when they were taken for "bath time" they just stood there whilst a guy hosed them down.

We have been here years ago. Now the park is renew and still under construction. We really like to see the elephants,drinking,making fun and making ‚ù§Ô∏è On the day it is very hot,so take umbrella ‚òîÔ∏è or take üß¢. Enjoy üòâ the üêò elephants

Visited the Orphanage's bathing site at around 10.30am. The elephants are already in their natural bath. Honestly after walking through the street full of souvenir shops and suddenly this open space appear, seeing the elephant against the greenaries and blue sky is quite a sight to behold. Do look out for the men enticing you to feed the elephants with the oranges they provides, it willcost 100rupee. I next visited the Orphanage itself but only a handful of elephants are there. Do wait till 12noon when the elephants walk home from their bathing site. This is where the elephants walking by the souvenir shops and crossing the busy road to return to the orphanage. There are some reports that saying this Orphanage is ill-treating the elephants.  Yes I do see some elephants been chained at the leg but there are also signage to explain that they need to chain some of the more agressive male elephants to prevent them from attacking. So is it ill-treating or disciplining - I guess it's up to individual to decipher.

We enjoyed our visit to the Elephant orphanage, we arrived for bathing time and watched them enjoying relaxed time in the water but watching the heard walking back to the orphanage is a sight to behold. Unforgettable

You are charged 3000Rs to see 10 elephants in a enclosure, some of them chained. Today " no elephant bath" because water is to high, "no baby milking" without any other explanation. Another zone is closed to the public. Just the explanation panels are well done and interesting, but in half an hour you have finished the visit. Really disapointing.

I unfortunately ended up here while traveling through Sri Lanka and it's clear to me that this is nothing but a tourist trap of captured and chained elephants. We were approached several times by people asking for us to pay more by riding/bathing these poor elephants that are anything but "wild". Please don't encourage this place to continue the mistreatment of these poor animals.

I‚Äôm unsure how I feel about this place...they seems to treat the elephants well but they don‚Äôt give you enough information about their cause. I was nice to see the elephants play in the river and I can understand that they need to chain the males because some can be aggressive, though it was distressing to see them chained and poked at.

In a few words, absolutely terrible. They claim to be an elephant ‚Äúorphanage‚Äù but it‚Äôs all just a business scam. Through fault of my own, I trusted the name and was hoping to be touched, I was wrong. First off, the drive there is like an hour and a half and absolutely not worth what you are going to see. The elephants are obviously terrified of the staff so I‚Äôll just let you imagine what happens after closing hours and the price to get in is 3000RP per person which is dreadfully overpriced (~16$). You basically just walk around and watch them in an small closed area. The only thing I‚Äôll give them was the bathing part, the landscape was quite nice. However, If you want to actually bath them, that would be a few bucks more. It‚Äôs a tourist trap and please do not make the same mistake as me, it is just a terrible ZOO.

It was nice to see the Orphanage and I am pleased that the Elephants are being protected. I was a bit upset with the section for treating the 'angry' teenage elephants were they are tied up with no room to move and are basically having to dance on the spot to keep moving. That said the rest of the orphanage was big and spacious allowing the Elephants to roam. It was also nice to see them enjoying the water (in the big river) splashing around and playing. Glad we went but would not rush back again.

Before we came here, we did much research on the humane treatment of their elephants.  The primary objection that most people have is that male elephants have a chain on them when they are bathing.  This is to prevent them from attacking other males.  The elephants and their trainers had a grand time taking a bath and there was nothing cruel about it.  If they were released to the wild, they would die.  What other solution would you offer.  Seeing 40 plus elephants was a once in a life time experience and we would highly recommend it.

After visiting the wonderful Elephant Nature Park in Chiang Mai a few years ago, this was a poorly executed excuse for a rescue park, where in truth the Elephants looked stressed and far from happy. At the feeding station, we declined feeding an elephant on the grounds that its keeper had a big stick with sharp end to keep the elephant in step. It may be needed, but it looks as if the elephants are are not treated nearly as well as in Chiang Mai. We then crossed the road to watch the elephants bathe, only to find that they are are chained in the water and literally unable to move, does not look like fun to me. I totally get why some people love this place as its the closest they ever get to seeing elephants in a wild setting, but I would say better to do a safari, which is close by.
There was promissed also a visit at the river with the elefants, but they wont do that after paying Overall to shot, to expansive and agreemsts, they dont care

This place was first in our itinerary in a 10 day Sri Lanka tour and were very happy to see how the Elephants are treated. We were on time to witness the elephant bathing session on river close to main entrance gate. I mean accross the road. Local seller sell food stuff to be fed to elephants and it was really great experience. There are more than 40 elephants taken care at this place and whatever I saw I felt they are really taken care by staff. If you have time you can also plan to give bath to elephant at extra charges. Do visit elephant poo paper factory to experience the making if paper from poo. Overall a great experience

Visited here on 19th Jan,2019. This orphanage established by the Sri Lanka Department of Wildlife Conservation is home to around 80 elephants. They have fruit feeding activities.The elephants bathe and frolic in the Maha Oya stream. Plenty of British tourists sitting in the viewing areas of the restaurants here. The road near the entrance also has plenty of elephant themed souvenirs from t-shirts & paintings to magnets and puzzle piece toys for kids.

It was a great experience to watch the elephants bathe in the river, though some of the larger elephants have been chained. The orphanage does display a board stating why they chain the elephants - as measure of precaution to the public due to the size of the animals and other reasons. I was not entirely convinced mainly because the handlers had sharp objects which they use to direct the elephants. The place is great to visit and the local shops produce paper using elephant dung which was quite intriguing.  You can also bathe the elephants for an additional cost. The shops have great souvenirs.

Nothing more than exploitation. Most elephants were chained up and harassed by the workers with sharp sticks. Whenever a worker would approach the elephants, the elephants would run away in fear. So I'm guessing that they are treated very bad. The photos are not what it is really like. You should avoid this if you don't want to support animal cruelty.
It was a good experience at Pinnawala Elephant Orphanage. Because it is on the way to Kandy it can be visited else coming from Colombo or any other place specially for this is not the worth.

It is easy to judge and come to conclusions, yes on our visit there were a few elephants feeding and loose but the majority were chained for some reason and some were pacing and looked stressed. But we have to wonder what would happen to these magnificent beasts if they had not been rescued and left too fend for themselves. We did see some of them in the river walking freely. Before we went we did expext the elephants to be free and not chained, it would have been a good idea if we had been given the reasons as to why they were chained.

Animal cruelty. Avoid at all cost. Elephants get a trip to the river (when tides allow) and this is what appears in the site photos, however this is misleading, and the actual reserve is bleak. I would not go there again and would encourage others to do the same. Elephants were heavily chained and there is little to stimulate them here, and many seemed anxious and distressed. It makes me upset as i type this. DO NOT SUPPORT

The orphanage is great and the vast majority of the Elephants appear to be enjoying life. They have various areas and pens and so some are chanied. But without knowing why, you cannot really judge on it being cruel, given that so many are roaming free. If you go mid morning around 1030 or at 1430 in the afternoon you can see the elephants walked down to the river to bathe. It really is a beautiful sight and they appear to be thoroughly enjoying themselves. We enjoyed our visit and these elephants appear happy. Unlike the elephant tourist spots before or after Pinnawala which offer close ups and rides with the elephants. They are nothing but a rip off and it's distressing to see the elephants. We did stop off at the advice of our guide and wish we hadn't. A complete rip off. DO - Visit Pinnawala Elephant Orphange DONT - Visit any other tourist elephant spot before or after

This was a disappointing visit. Opposed to our tour description and guide books, the orphanage has no baby elephants, but a number of young elephants. You get close to the elephants, but there was not much activity when we visited.

It's not often that we get to see wild animals close up - least of all endangered  species  like the Asian elephant. But to see 75 of them in one place is incredibly privileged. This is the largest herd of Asian elephants in the world today in controlled ,protected surroundings. The orphanage  has been running since 1975 and the work it is doing is helping  to keep the species alive and all monies raised goes towards the continued  work of looking after these magnificent beasts. A MUST SER. Very highly recommended.

The actual sanctuary area is a bit of a letdown, not much to see, Elephants are semi wild and are orphaned or injured. Guests can watch the elephants bathing and playing in the nearby river and can also feed elephants if they are there at certain times.  This is a great opportunity to see elephants up close in an open, relaxed and somewhat natural environment.

I have been to an elephant sanctuary in Thailand a couple of years ago this was an exact opposite of that. I have seen elephants on the roads of Jaipur  treated with love too. This was drenched in economic greed and maximizing profit irrespective of the mental health of the elephants. No matter what they say about the chains around their feet it's wrong and enslaving. The handlers very-very rough. It was heart breaking to see

Apart from providing photo opportunities, this place is best forgotten. Firstly, if the exorbitant entry fees were put to good use, there would be improvement in the animal welfare. More to the point, the so called mahouts could be provided with some training and the two pronged metal implement confiscated. Pronging these majestic creatures  is utterly cruel and there are places overseas, where the metal prong has been discarded. When the animals are taken across back to their glorified cage, often a 'senior' mahout and an elephant lag behind providing close photo and feeding opportunities---at a cost of course

Whilst I am not a fan of animals being kept in captivity I was very pleasantly surprised by my visit. We were fortunate as the elephants were "bathing" in the fast flowing river, and it was amazing to see them frolic in the water. Thereafter we followed the elephants back to the enclosed arena. Definitely worth visiting NB -- there is a very big difference in the fee entrance for locals and foreigners

I was hoping that this would be a happy place but instead I left feeling very, very disappointed. One entry price for locals and an over-inflated price for foreign tourists, and I struggled to find anywhere which showed rehabilitation in action for these magnificent creatures. Elephants get a trip to the river (when tides allow) and this is what appears in the site photos, however this is misleading, and the actual reserve is bleak. I would not go there again and would encourage others to do the same. Elephants were heavily chained and there is little to stimulate them here, and many seemed anxious and distressed. We left (my wife in tears) after 15 minutes.

This place was a huge disappointment. My partner and I visited in January with the promise of seeing rescued elephants, living a life free from captivity with a heroic rescue story. We were highly disappointed and left after 10 minutes. First of all, we were charged around USD$30 each as a tourist to enter and upon arrival we saw elephants in distress, chained up with little room to move. They seemed extremely unhappy and some of the worst captivity I have ever seen. Please do not go here and do not support this ‚Äòorphanage‚Äô. a really good gesture to set up an orphanage to rescue the orphan elephants. chance to see the elephants up close, u can get to feed the elephants too.

Hello, I was in Pinnawala last October (2018) and it was a total scam as expected. The tourists arrive in a campus that is completely human-created as opposed to what the pictures seem to show, surrounded by elephant cages and yards where the elephants are being held captive with chains in place and keepers armed with spears. The elephants are paraded every few hours to the ''feeding area'' and the ''bathing river''. Both these areas are places to which the elephants are forced to walk to, clearly displaying signs of stress and resistance to the keepers. The smaller elephants that they call ''babies'' are used for public demonstrations of milk nursing. A local guide explained to us that these babies are in fact adult elephants with over 8 years that are kept in confined places and fed milk so they remain small and cute for the tourists to believe in the whole ''orphanage'' thing. I believe this orphanage started as a place for rescued elephants, but nowadays it's clearly only a zoo for captive mistreated elephants that should be in programs to be returned to the wild. Many guides admit to take tourists here only because of its international popularity, against their own beliefs. IN SUM, if you have the time, for the SAME PRICE of visiting this scam, you can go on a full day safari at the beautiful national parks of Sri Lanka and see wild elephants happy in their proper habitats. Please spread the word and complain to your travel agency as most of the european or any international proposed itineraries in Sri Lanka propose Pinnawala as a must, and this has to absolutely change, together with the overpriced fake spice garden tours.

Spent 2 weeks volunteering here as a family so gained some insight into the orphanage. The orphanage would love to see all elephants in the wild, unfortunately this is impossible with pressures on land use by a growing population.  They cant introduce elephants to an existing wild herd as they would not be accepted.  All elephants in the orphanage have been raised in captivity so would seek out people if released and this would in turn create conflict risking the elephants life. The mahouts do shout and use ashoks with elephants to ensure public safety.  To see behind the public face and watch them tenderly go over the elephants skin for 2 hours looking for problems shows their true feelings towards the animals.  They shout at the cleaners if the elephant houses are not sufficiently cleaned. The prices are fair for tourists and cheaper for locals to encourage locals to visit, learn and take an interest in their own wildlife.  This is a government run organisation so the prices are set in Colombo, not by the orphanage.  The extra fee for feeding or bathing elephants is likewise set by the politicians. The Elephant in the Room - chains.  These are necessary to manage the herd in a small area to keep public, staff and elephants safe.  Injured, sick and pregnant elephants are kept separate, but still taken for free time at the river away from the main herd. There are 19 elephants housed here which have been seized from illegal owners and are awaiting court cases so can't be put with the herd. In all we really enjoyed our 2 weeks here giving us an insight not gained during a short visit.  Volunteering is hard work and not for everybody.  We learnt about the politics behind a lot of decisions and saw the love held for these wonderful creatures by all the staff at the orphanage.

There are a lot of misleading reviews about Pinnawala. I've been twice - earlier this month and 21 years ago - and I've enjoyed the experience both times. The price of 2500 rupees (about ¬£11 per person) is quite high but much lower than I've seen online where it's often stated at $20 per person. There's not too much to do. Our driver went in with us which we thought a bit odd until we realised he knew exactly where to go and when to make sure we got the best experience. We went first to the elephant 'paddocks' where the ladies were hanging around eating and waiting for bath time. In a separate area, the boys were getting ready to go the river. Nothing can really prepare you for seeing a massive herd of elephants on the move. The boys went first, strolling through the orphanage, out to the road and down to the river. Some are chained - for their safety and everybody else's. I don't think it's a bad thing. Once the boys were on their way, the lady elephants followed. We watched the bath time for nearly 2 hours. Our driver urged us to a brilliant watching space in a cafe which we really appreciated. In two hours you have plenty of time to watch and observe the different personalities amongst the elephants. There are the cheeky younger boys, the stubborn old ladies, the frisky and the laid-back all hanging out together. People have commented on the use of 'spikes' or 'guides'. We was the metal guides being used by the mahoots but always very gently and never with any violence. The love of the handlers for their pachyderm pals was clear to all. One old lady - quite possibly the grande dame of the herd - spent an hour standing knee deep trying to avoid a wash. Her mahoot gently urged her into deeper water, taking his time and using his 'guide' to help scrape old mud off her head and back. Eventually she gave in and rolled over in the water to let him clean her properly. Some are chained in the water but didn't seem distressed about it. A couple of young females made a jovial bid for freedom on the far banks and were laughingly chased down and returned to the herd. If you're looking for lots of action, this may disappoint. If you have the patience to watch and wait, you'll probably love it as much as I did. One comment. I think the management should consider rebranding this as an Elephant Home rather than an Elephant Orphanage since it seems to create elevated expectations of lots of babies and at present there really aren't many at all. The purpose of the home is to give safe haven to elephants, not to go looking for unwanted babies. Back in the days of the Civil War, a lot of babies were orphaned by their parents being killed (accidentally or intentionally) so there were more little ones to see. These days they do have a few babies but I suspect that's more an outcome of boy and girl elephants getting friendly rather than any kind of captive breeding programme.
